title: SCDSS v. C. H. Doe
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDTIAL VALUE AND SHOULD NOT BE
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE
  STATE OF
  
      
  SOUTH CAROLINA
In
  The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				South Carolina Department of Social
      Services, Respondent,
				v.
				C. H. Doe, W. R. Roe, J. Moe, A. J.
      Poe, Defendants, of whom C. H. Doe is Appellant.
				
					In the interest of: A. J. Poe, Jr. 09/24/93,
					a minor under the age of 18.
				
			
		
	


Appeal From
  
    
  Charleston
  
  County
Â Jocelyn B. Cate, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion
  No. 2007-UP-403
Submitted October
  1, 2007 â€“ Filed October 2, 2007Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				M. Dawes Cooke, Jr, and Alissa DeCarlo, of
				
				Charleston, for Appellant.
				Paul C. White, of Moncks Corner, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In this family court action, C. H. Doe (Grandfather) appeals the family
  courtâ€™s order removing his grandson, A. J. Poe, Jr. (Grandson), from his
  custody.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The following facts were developed during the contested merits hearing on
  May 15, 2006.Â  Grandson was born on
  September 24, 1993,[2] and resided with Grandfather from that time until March 2004, when officers
  arrested Grandfather for fondling a neighborâ€™s child. Â At that time, the Department of Social
  Services (DSS) took Grandson into protective custody.Â  A report given to Jocelyn Multry, Grandsonâ€™s case manager, stated Grandson was
  molested by Grandfather who touched his genitals and that when Grandson urinated his genitals burned.Â 
 
Initially, Grandson did not reveal any of the sexual abuse, and he was
  referred to Low Country Childrenâ€™s Center.Â  It was not until almost a year later that Grandson began to talk
  about being sexually abused by Grandfather. Â By that point in time, Grandson had been
  sexually abused while in foster care.Â  Â Â Â 
Grandson testified Grandfather put his penis in Grandsonâ€™s buttocks and
  that Grandfather touched him inappropriately.Â  Grandson also stated Grandfather took
  pictures of him while he was naked.Â  Â 
Grandfather denied ever sexually abusing Grandson.Â  He testified Grandson lied and that DSS
  coerced him into making false statements.Â  Grandfather explained the only time he touched Grandson was when he
  was about five years old because he had issues with wiping himself after going
  to the bathroom. Â Â As to the
  allegations regarding the burning sensation while Grandson urinated,
  Grandfather stated he gave him a bath in diluted bleach and when Grandson
  urinated in the tub the ammonia and bleach mixed together.[3]Â  Grandfather also stated that he then
  put Vaseline on Grandsonâ€™s hand and told him to apply it to his burning genital
  area. Â Â 
After the hearing, the family court issued its order.Â  The order prohibited Grandfather from
  having any contact with Grandson.Â  Further,
  the family court found reunification was not in Grandsonâ€™s best interest and,
  therefore, did not recommend any services be provided to Grandfather.Â  The family court ordered Grandfatherâ€™s
  name to be placed in the central registry of child abuse and neglect due to his
  sexual abuse of Grandson.Â  Â The family court retained jurisdiction to
  review the treatment plan with respect to possibly placing Grandson with his
  biological mother.Â  Â The family court noted Grandfatherâ€™s objection
  to the treatment/placement plan.Â  Although
  Grandfatherâ€™s brief states that his custodial rights â€œwere terminated,â€ no
  formal termination of parental rights action has yet occurred.Â  Grandfather appeals the order of removal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The family court shall not order the removal of a child â€œunless
  the court finds that the allegations of the petition are supported by a
  preponderance of evidence including a finding that the child is abused or
  neglected. . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-736 (Supp. 2006).Â  Â â€œIn
  appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its
  own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v. Moghaddassi, 364 S.C.182, 189, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (
  
      
  Ct. App. 2005) (citation
  omitted).Â  â€œOur broad scope of
  review does not require us to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact
  the trial judge was in a better position to asses the credibility of the
  witnesses.â€Â  S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings,
  345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Dorchester
    County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C.
  445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Grandfather argues the family court erred in removing Grandson
  after finding Grandson was abused or neglected under section 20-7-490 of the
  South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).Â  We
  disagree. Â 
Initially, Grandfather argues DSS failed to raise
  allegations of sexual abuse against him prior to the contested merits hearing.Â  Grandfather contends the complaint only
  alleged sexual abuse regarding the neighborâ€™s child rather than sexual abuse
  against Grandson.Â  Therefore, he avers
  his due process rights were violated because he was unaware that sexual abuse
  regarding Grandson would be an issue at the hearing.Â Â Â  We disagree.
As a threshold matter, this argument is not preserved for our
  review.Â  To preserve an issue for
  appellate review, the issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but
  must have been raised to and ruled upon by the family court.Â 
      
      
      Charleston
      
        County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson, 368
  S.C. 87, 104-05, 627 S.E.2d 765, 775 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543,
  546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first
  time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court
  to be preserved for appellate review.â€)).Â  Grandfather did not raise this issue to the family court.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved for
  our review.
Even if the issue were properly before us, we find no merit
  to the argument because Grandfatherâ€™s sexual abuse regarding Grandson was tried
  by consent.Â  See Woods v. Rabon, 295 S.C. 343, 347, 368 S.E.2d 471, 474 (Ct. App.
  1988) (â€œIf neither party timely objects to evidence raising issues not pleaded,
  each is deemed impliedly to consent to the trial of such issues.â€). When Grandson
  testified regarding Grandfatherâ€™s sexual abuse, Grandfather did not object to
  the testimony on this point.Â  In addition, during his testimony,
  Grandfather explicitly denied ever having sexually abused Grandson and addressed
  the allegations raised during Grandsonâ€™s testimony.Â  Therefore, Grandfather consented to trying
  the issue of his sexual abuse of Grandson.Â  Further, the complaint for removal put Grandfather on sufficient notice
  that allegations of sexual abuse regarding Grandson would be an issue during
  the hearing.Â  The complaint alleged
  Grandfather â€œsexually abused and physically neglected the minor child . . . .â€Â  The
  complaint also stated Grandfather â€œwould touch the minor child . . . buttocks
  once he used the bathroom because of his function level.â€Â  Â Accordingly, Grandfather was fully apprised of
  the sexual abuse charges against him and we find no merit to Grandfatherâ€™s
  argument on this point.
Next, Grandfather argues the evidence fails to support the
  family courtâ€™s finding of sexual abuse under section 20-7-490.Â  He contends the only evidence at trial that
  he sexually abused Grandson was Grandsonâ€™s own testimony during the
  hearing.Â  Grandfather maintains because Grandson
  waited so long after removal before disclosing the abuse that Grandson was
  somehow coerced into making the allegations.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-490 provides a child is abused or neglected
  when a person responsible for a child â€œcommits or allows to be committed against the child a sexual offense as defined by laws of this state.
  . . .â€ Â The evidence presented during the
  hearing shows that Grandfather did sexually abuse Grandson. Grandson testified
  at length to the sexual abuse he suffered.Â  He also testified that initially he was afraid to disclose the abuse
  because he was afraid of his Grandfather.Â  Further, Mary Green, Grandsonâ€™s
  therapist, testified that in most sexual abuse cases, children do not reveal
  the abuse until some time later. Â 
In addition, the order of the family court shows it
  considered the fact Grandfather disputed Grandsonâ€™s allegations against him.Â  The order references Grandfatherâ€™s belief
  Grandson was lying and finds Grandsonâ€™s testimony â€œto be extremely credible.â€Â  Therefore,
  Grandfatherâ€™s theory that Grandson was fabricating the sexual abuse allegations
  was at issue during the hearing.Â  The
  family court heard and weighed the testimony, including the fact Grandfatherâ€™s own witness testified that he believed
  Grandson was an honest child.Â  Â Accordingly,
  the preponderance of the evidence supports the family courtâ€™s conclusion that
  Grandfather sexually abused Grandson and the family court properly removed
  Grandson from Grandfatherâ€™s custody.Â   
Therefore,
  the order of the family court is  
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] On June 8, 1999, the family court
  awarded Grandfather sole custody of Grandson. Â Â 
[3] The record is unclear as to whether Grandfather did
  this because of red bug bites or because he believed â€œbleach cures practically
  anything.â€

title: Dew v. Santee Cooper
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Willie J. Dew,
      Employee, Respondent,
				v.
				Santee Cooper,
      Employer, through South Carolina Public Service Authority, Carrier, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Florence County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-404
Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  October 3, 2007Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED 



	
		
			
				Kirsten Leslie Barr, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
				Joseph T. McElveen, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  action originated from a workersâ€™ compensation claim filed by Willie Joe Dew
  against his employer, Santee Cooper.Â  Santee Cooper appeals the decision of the
  Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, which found Dewâ€™s
  injuries to his right knee and back were compensable and ordered payment by
  lump sum to be allocated over Dewâ€™s lifetime.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On
  April 30, 2001, Dew was in the process of loading two vehicles onto a low-boy trailer
  when his right leg gave way causing him to fall backwards off the trailer.Â  The
  low-boy trailer was approximately three and one half feet tall.Â  Dew worked about
  three hours prior to the accident on April 30th.Â   
Following
  his fall, Dew went to the emergency room, which recorded right knee and right
  hip injuries.Â  Santee Cooperâ€™s physician, Dr. Marcus Schaefer, examined Dew on
  the day of the fall.Â  Dr. Schaefer recorded that Dew fell backwards off of the
  low-boy and diagnosed him with a right knee strain, a right hip strain, and a
  contusion.Â Â Â  Â Â 
The first report for Workersâ€™
  Compensation, Form 12A, was submitted following the accident.Â  Subsequently,
  Dew received temporary compensation, which was interrupted multiple times when
  Dew attempted to return to work.Â  Dew filed a claim by submitting a Form 50 on April
  25, 2003, which listed injuries to his back, right leg, right hip, and right
  testicle, as well as psychological effects from the fall on April 30, 2001.Â 
  Santee Cooper filed a Form 21, requesting a hearing to stop payment of
  compensation.Â   
The
  single commissioner held a hearing on November 14, 2003.Â  The single
  commissioner concluded Dew was totally and permanently disabled under sections
  42-9-10 and 42-9-30 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2002).Â  The single
  commissioner ordered Santee Cooper to pay Dew a lump sum payment, not to exceed
  a total of five hundred weeks of compensation.Â  The order allocated the lump
  sum payment to Dew over his lifetime.Â   
Santee
  Cooper requested the Appellate Panel review the single commissionerâ€™s order,
  citing forty-five exceptions.Â  The Appellant Panel affirmed the single
  commissioner and adopted her order in full.Â   
Santee
  Cooper then appealed the Appellate Panelâ€™s order to the circuit court.Â  The
  circuit court affirmed the Appellate Panel.Â  This appeal follows.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The
  findings of an administrative agency, such as the Appellate Panel, are presumed
  correct and will only be set aside if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Rodney
    v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 519, 466 S.E.2d 357,
  359 (1996).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence which, considering the
  record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that
  the administrative agency reached.â€Â  Gibson v. Florence Country Club,
  282 S.C. 384, 386, 318 S.E.2d 365, 367 (1984) (internal quotations omitted).
When
  conflicting medical evidence is presented, the Appellate
  Panelâ€™s findings of fact are conclusive.Â  Grayson v. Carter Rhoad Furniture, 317
  S.C. 306, 309, 454 S.E.2d 320, 321-22 (1995).Â  The duty to determine facts is
  placed solely on the Appellate Panel, and the court reviewing the decision of
  the Appellate Panel has no authority to determine factual issues but must
  remand the matter to the Appellate Panel for further proceedings if necessary. Â Fox
    v. Newberry County Memâ€™l Hosp., 319 S.C. 278, 280, 461 S.E.2d 392,
  394 (1995).Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Right Knee Injury
Santee
  Cooper argues the Appellate Panel erred regarding Dewâ€™s right knee for three
  reasons: 1) by holding compensation for Dewâ€™s right knee injury was properly
  before the Appellate Panel; 2) by failing to find Dewâ€™s right knee injury was
  time barred; and 3) by finding substantial evidence supported Dewâ€™s claim for
  his right knee.Â  We disagree.
a.
  The Compensation Issue Was Properly Before The Appellate Panel
Santee
  Cooper submits because Dew â€œnever legally claimed any entitlement to benefits
  for his knee or leg,â€ the issue was not before the Appellate Panel.Â  We
  disagree.
In his
  Form 50, a workersâ€™ compensation form used to file a claim, Dew listed his
  back, right leg, and right hip as injuries sustained from the April 30, 2001
  accident.Â  Additionally, Dew testified before the single commissioner that on
  the day of the accident his right leg â€œwent awayâ€ and he fell onto his back.Â 
  On the day of the fall, Santee
  Cooperâ€™s doctor diagnosed Dew with a right knee strain, a right hip strain, and
  a contusion.Â  Therefore, Dew presented sufficient evidence to place his right
  knee injury properly before the Appellate Panel.Â Â Â   
b.
  Dewâ€™s Claim Is Not Time Barred
Santee Cooper
  alleges Dewâ€™s claim for his right knee injury is time barred under section
  42-15-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).Â  We disagree.
Section 42-15-40 states,
  â€œThe right to compensation under this title is barred unless a claim
  is filed with the commission within two years after an accident . . . .â€
The accident
  occurred on April 30, 2001, and Dew filed his Form 50 on April 25, 2003.Â  The
  Form 50 states Dew â€œsustained an accidental injury to his back, right leg,
  [and] right hip.â€Â  Further, Dew notes on the form that he fell when his leg
  gave way.Â  Additionally, the Form 50 states Dew was filing the form as a
  claim.Â  Therefore, Dew followed section 42-15-40 by filing a claim for his
  right knee within the statutory time limit.Â   
c.
  Substantial Evidence Supports The Appellate Panelâ€™s Finding 
Santee Cooper
  argues substantial evidence does not support the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding that
  Dewâ€™s right knee was injured by an accident arising out of Dewâ€™s employment.Â 
  We disagree.
Substantial
  evidence is defined as evidence that would allow reasonable minds to reach the
  same conclusion as the Appellate Panel.Â  Gibson, 282 S.C. at 386, 318
  S.E.2d at 367.Â  Additionally, â€œthe trier of fact [which is the Appellate Panel]
  is not necessarily bound by, and need not accept or believe, medical or other
  expert testimony, even when it is unanimous, uncontroverted, or
  uncontradicted.â€Â  100A C.J.S. Workersâ€™ Compensation Â§1023 (2000). 
 
Dew testified at
  trial that on April 30, 2001, his â€œright leg went awayâ€ causing him to fall.Â  Dr.
  Preston B. Fitzgerald, a chiropractor, determined to a reasonable degree of
  chiropractic orthopedic probability the injuries Dew suffered were from the
  April 30, 2001 accident.Â  Dr. Stephen Rawe noted that Dew â€œsustained a work
  related injury on 4/30/01.â€Â  Additionally, Dr. Schaefer, the company doctor,
  noted, â€œI do not believe [Dewâ€™s] knee injury is work related, but [it] can
  be.â€Â  Therefore, substantial evidence supports finding Dewâ€™s right knee was
  injured by the April 30, 2001 accident.  
Santee Cooper
  further disputes the causation of Dewâ€™s knee injury by noting Dew saw Dr.
  Fitzgerald prior to the accident complaining of knee pain.Â   
In Gordon
  v. E. I. Du Pont De Nemours & Co., the South Carolina Supreme Court
  stated that a latent or quiescent weakened, but not disabling, condition resulting
  from disease or previous accidental injury that is aggravated, accelerated, or
  activated within the course of employment may result in a compensable disability.Â 
  228 S.C. 67, 76, 88 S.E.2d 844, 848 (1955).
Prior to the
  accident, Dewâ€™s knee bothered him for a number of years following an incident
  when he jumped over a ditch.Â  On April 16, 2001, Dew saw Dr. Fitzgerald
  regarding pain in his right knee.Â  Dr. Fitzgerald referred Dew to an
  orthopedist, whom Dew saw on April 20, 2001.Â  An MRI was performed on Dewâ€™s
  right knee on April 27, 2001.Â  The radiologist, Dr. Robin Daum-Kowalski,
  concluded Dewâ€™s right knee had a lateral meniscal tear with related separation,
  joint effusion, and a medial meniscal signal without a tear.Â   
Dr. George Dawson
  and Dr. Robert Eagerton signed documents instructing Dew to return to full-duty
  work on April 30, 2001, the date of the accident.Â  Additionally, Dr. Marcus
  Schaefer recorded that Dewâ€™s knee completely gave out on the day of the
  accident for the first time and subsequently gave out four additional times.Â 
 

	The Appellate Panelâ€™s
  adopted order explains:
	
		The
  Claimantâ€™s accident aggravated his pre-existing condition to his knee. . . .Â 
  Although the knee would have required surgery even without the accident, the
  fact is that everyone reasonably believed on the date of injury that Claimant
  was able to work with no restrictions. . . . Claimant worked several hours,
  putting considerable strain on his right leg and knee.Â  The knee â€œgave awayâ€, (sic)
  causing him to fall. Â Under the circumstances of this claim, the back and right
  leg injuries both arose out of and in the course of employment.
	

The Appellate Panelâ€™s
  finding that Dewâ€™s knee injury arose out of an accident within his scope of
  employment is supported by substantial evidence and, therefore, is not
  reversible error.Â   
II. Total Disability
Santee Cooper
  argues the Appellate Panel erred in finding Dew is entitled to benefits for
  permanent and total disability under sections 42-9-10 and 42-9-30 of the South
  Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) due to a lack of evidentiary support and the applicable
  law.[1] Â We disagree.
In Wigfall
  v. Tideland Util., Inc., the South Carolina Supreme Court interpreted section
  42-9-10.Â  Our Supreme Court elucidated three ways a claimant may obtain total
  disability: (1) by demonstrating one of the injuries designated as total
  disabilities in section 42-9-10; (2) by showing a nonscheduled injury under
  section 42-9-30, which caused such a loss in earning capacity to make the
  claimant totally disabled; and (3) by suffering a section 42-9-30 scheduled
  injury and an additional injury to his body.Â  354 S.C. 100, 105-06, 580 S.E.2d
  100, 102-03 (2003).Â  This third option is explored below.
In Singleton
  v. Young Lumber Co., 236 S.C. 454, 471, 114 S.E.2d 837,
  845 (1960), our Supreme Court stated:

	Where
  the injury is confined to the scheduled member, and there is no impairment of
  any other part of the body because of such injury, the employee is limited to
  the scheduled compensation, even though other considerations such as age, lack
  of training, or other conditions peculiar to the individual, effect (sic) a
  total or partial industrial incapacity. To obtain compensation in addition to
  that scheduled for the injured member, claimant must show that some other part
  of his body is affected.

Section
  42-9-30 lists various injuries and the amount and period of payments for the
  corresponding scheduled injuries.Â  Section 42-9-30(19) lists the following
  scheduled injury:

	For the total loss of use of the back, sixty-six and two-thirds
  percent of the average weekly wages during three hundred weeks. The
  compensation for partial loss of use of the back shall be such proportions of
  the periods of payment herein provided for total loss as such partial loss
  bears to total loss, except that in cases where there is fifty percent or more
  loss of use of the back, in which event the injured employee shall be deemed to
  have suffered total and permanent disability and compensated therefor under
  paragraph two of Â§ 42-9-10.

The
  evidence regarding Dewâ€™s injuries does not need to come solely from doctors.Â 
  â€œUnless the question of the extent of partial loss of use under Code Â§ 42-9-30
  is so technically complicated as to require exclusively expert testimony, lay
  testimony is admissible.â€Â  Linen v. Ruscon Constr. Co., 286 S.C.
  67, 68, 332 S.E.2d 211, 212 (1985).Â  Additionally, â€œ[t]he commission may find a degree of disability different from that
  suggested by expert testimony.â€Â  Lyles v. Quantum Chem. Co.
    (Emery), 315 S.C. 440, 445, 434 S.E.2d 292, 295 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
 
In
  the case at hand, Dr. W. S. Edwards, Jr. used his experience rather than the guidelines
  to determine Dew had a 10% back impairment.Â  Dr. Rawe believed Dew suffered a
  5% back impairment.Â  Dr. Edwards further stated that Dew should not repeatedly
  lift anything, even if the item only weighed five pounds.Â  Also, Dew was not to
  sit or stand for extended periods of time.Â  Dew testified regarding his pain
  and his difficulty in accomplishing normal tasks such as driving or regular
  hygiene practices.Â   
Regardless
  of whether the Appellate Panelâ€™s assessment that Dew sustained greater than 50%
  impairment to his back is correct, Dew suffered a back injury on April 30, 2001,
  within the scope of his employment.Â  Therefore, substantial evidence exists in
  the record that Dew suffered impairment to his back, which is a scheduled
  injury under section 42-9-30(19).
Now
  that a section 42-9-30 schedule injury has been established, this Court again
  turns to Wigfall and section 42-9-10.Â  Under Wigfall, a claimant
  may recover total disability if he suffered a section 42-9-30 scheduled injury
  and an additional injury to his body.Â  Wigfall, 354 S.C. at 105-06, 580
  S.E.2d at 102-03.Â  As discussed above, Dew suffered his scheduled back injury
  and an additional injury to his knee during the accident.Â  Therefore, the
  Appellate Panel did not err by finding Dew suffered total disability.Â 
  Accordingly, we need not address any remaining
  issues regarding Dewâ€™s injury rating.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe
  appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s)
  appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€).
III. Loss of Use Factors
Santee
  Cooper argues the Appellate Panel erred in determining Dew sustained a greater
  than 50% loss of use to his back because the Appellate Panelâ€™s order considers
  factors outside of the medical model.Â  We decline to reach this issue as the
  above determination of total disability is dispositive.Â  Hagood v.
    Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 199, 607 S.E.2d 707, 711 (2005) (stating an
  appellate court need not reach remaining issues when an issue is dispositive).
IV. Payment of
  Compensation
Santee Cooper
  contests the Appellate Panelâ€™s allocation of Dewâ€™s compensation in a lump sum to
  be paid over Dewâ€™s lifetime by arguing the payment method circumvents federal
  law governing social security disability benefits.Â  We disagree.
Section 42-9-301 of
  the South Carolina Code (1976) provides a specialized scope of review for
  appellate courts when determining if the Appellate Panel properly granted a
  lump sum payment.Â  This applicable scope of review is whether the Appellate
  Panel abused its discretion.Â  Thompson v. S.C. Steel Erectors, 369 S.C.
  606, 612, 632 S.E.2d 874, 878 (Ct. App. 2006).

	Further, section
  42-9-301 states:
	
		Whenever
  any weekly payment has been continued for not less than six weeks, the
  liability therefor may, when the employee so requests and the commission deems
  it not to be contrary to the best interest of the employee or his dependents,
  or when it will prevent undue hardship on the employer or his insurance
  carrier, without prejudicing the interest of the employee or his dependents, be
  redeemed, in whole or in part, by the payment by the employer of a lump sum
  which shall be fixed by the commission . . . . 
	

Section 42-9-10 of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) limits compensation to five hundred weeks
  and prohibits lump sum payments for a person entitled to lifetime benefits,
  such as paraplegics, quadriplegics, or individuals with physical brain damage.
In this case, the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s order grants Dew a lump sum payment of his workerâ€™s
  compensation benefits not to exceed 500 weeks.Â  Once the appropriate lump sum
  is determined, the order provides this lump sum should be allocated to Dew for
  the remainder of his life expectancy, which totaled 25.36 years.Â  The Appellate
  Panel found no evidence indicating Santee Cooper would be prejudiced by making
  the lump sum payment.Â   
We
  hold that the Appellate Panel did not abuse its discretion in providing Dew a
  lump sum payment to be allocated over the remainder of his life expectancy.Â 
  Santee Cooper is not prejudiced because it still compensates Dew for 500 weeks,
  the maximum time period.Â  Dew may receive this payment in a lump sum, which may
  even be allocated over a longer period of time; however, Santee Cooper pays the
  same amount regardless of the method the Appellate Panel believed best served
  Dew.  
Santee Cooperâ€™s main
  criticism of the order regarding payment hinges on an allegation that this
  method proscribed by the Appellate Panelâ€™s adopted order improperly affects
  Dewâ€™s potential Social Security benefits.Â   
Rule
  201(b), SCACR, states, â€œOnly a party aggrieved by an order, judgment, or sentence may
  appeal.â€Â  Santee Cooper is not an aggrieved party.Â  A party is
  aggrieved if a judgment or order bears directly on his or her interest.Â  Shaw
    v. City of Charleston, 351 S.C. 32, 36-37, 567 S.E.2d 530, 532 (Ct. App.
  2002) (â€œThe word â€˜aggrievedâ€™ refers to a substantial grievance, a denial
  of some personal or property right, or the imposition on a party of a burden or
  obligation.Â  An aggrieved party or person is one who is injured
  in a legal sense; one who has suffered an injury to person or property.â€) Â Â (internal quotations and citations omitted).Â  Consequently, a party which is
  not aggrieved by a courtâ€™s decision is prohibited from bringing an appeal.Â 
  This is true even if the courtâ€™s decision may be erroneous and
  prejudicial to some other personâ€™s rights and interests.Â  Id.
In
  the present case, even if we assumed the decision below somehow improperly
  affects Dewâ€™s Social Security benefits, this in no way affects Santee Cooperâ€™s
  interests.Â  Thus, Santee Cooper is not an aggrieved party.Â  Other
  considerations prevent us from adjudicating Santee Cooperâ€™s claim.Â   
â€œThe
  function of appellate courts is not to give opinions on merely abstract or
  theoretical matters, but only to decide actual controversies injuriously
  affecting the rights of some party to the litigation.â€ Sloan v. Greenville County, 356 S.C. 531, 552, 590 S.E.2d 338, 349 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  An
  appellate court examines justiciable controversies, which are real and substantial
  controversies, which are ripe and appropriate for judicial determination instead
  of merely contingent, hypothetical, or abstract disputes.Â  Spivey ex rel.
    Spivey v. Carolina Crawler, 367 S.C. 154, 160, 624 S.E.2d 435, 438 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  Therefore, issues that are not ripe are not appropriately before
  this Court.Â  Id.
This
  issue is not yet ripe.Â  Dew does not receive Social Security disability
  benefits at the present time.Â  If Dew does apply for such benefits, the Social
  Security Administration will be charged with the determination of any
  applicable set-offs.Â   
Additionally,
  to institute an action a plaintiff must first have standing. Â Joytime
    Distribs. & Amusement Co. v. State, 338 S.C. 634, 639, 528 S.E.2d 647, 649 (1999).Â 
  â€œTo have standing, one must have a personal stake in the subject
  matter of the lawsuit, i.e., one must be a real party in interest.â€Â  Charleston
    County Sch. Dist. v. Charleston County Election Commâ€™n, 336 S.C. 174,
  181, 519 S.E.2d 567, 571 (1999).Â  â€œA real party in interest is one who has
  a real, material, or substantial interest in the subject matter of the action,
  as opposed to one who has only a nominal or technical interest in the action.â€Â  Anchor Point, Inc. v. Shoals Sewer Co., 308 S.C. 422, 428, 418 S.E.2d
  546, 549 (1992).Â   
For
  a plaintiff to have taxpayer standing,
  the party must demonstrate some overriding public purpose or concern to confer standing to sue on behalf of his
  or her fellow taxpayers.Â  Sloan, 356 S.C. at 549, 590 S.E.2d at 347-48.Â 
  Further, taxpayer standing developed from taxpayers suing municipalities, not a
  former employee.Â  See id.; Beaufort County v. Trask, 349 S.C. 522, 529-30, 563 S.E.2d 660, 664 (Ct.
  App. 2002).
Santee
  Cooper lacks standing to bring this issue.Â  Merely being a taxpayer does not
  create standing to challenge the Appellate Panelâ€™s adopted order as Santee
  Cooper was not personally injured by the Appellate Panelâ€™s adopted order.Â  Therefore,
  the Appellate Panelâ€™s disposition of Dewâ€™s compensation does not create any
  justiciable controversy in this case, and the Appellate Panel did not abuse its
  discretion.
CONCLUSION
Dewâ€™s knee injury was properly before the Appellate
  Panel, and substantial evidence supported the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding that Dew
  injured his knee and his back during the course of his employment.Â  This dual
  injury allowed the Appellate Panel to find Dew was permanently and totally
  disabled.Â  Further, the Appellate Panel did not abuse its discretion in its
  determination of appropriate compensation payments for Dew.Â   
Accordingly,
  the circuit courtâ€™s rulings are  
AFFIRMED. [2]
STILWELL,
  SHORT, AND WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The South Carolina General Assembly recently amended South Carolinaâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation laws.Â  These statutory changes affect claims for
  injuries occurring on or after July 1, 2007.Â  See 2007 S.C. Acts 111,
  Part IV, Section 2 (â€œExcept as otherwise provided for in this act, this act takes
  effect July 1, 2007, or, if ratified after July 1, 2007, and except otherwise
  stated, upon approval by the Governor and applies to injuries that occur on
    or after this date.â€) (emphasis added).Â  This case involves
  an injury which occurred on April 30, 2001.Â   
[2] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Clark v. State
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Douglas R.
      Clark, Petitioner
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-411
  Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October 4, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott and
  Assistant Attorney General Karen Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Douglas
  R. Clark appeals the denial of his petition for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â 
  We affirm.[1]Â   
BACKGROUND FACTS
On
  June 16, 1998, Cosette Lemon arrived at her apartment at about 11:15 p.m. Â As
  she entered her home with a hamper of clothes, she pushed the door closed, but
  did not get it shut all the way. Â She put the hamper down in her living room
  and then went to lower some blinds.Â  She heard a sound at the door, but thought
  it was her boyfriend, Terry Shackett who usually came home from work about that
  time.Â  As she turned, she saw the profile of a man standing in the door.Â  The
  man told Lemon her boyfriend told him to come on in.Â  As Lemon looked toward
  the kitchen, the man grabbed her, jerked her around, and shoved her face down
  into the couch.Â  He pulled her up off the couch and told her they were going to
  the bedroom.Â  He pushed her down on the bed and was choking her.Â  He grabbed a
  pillow case and told her to put it in her mouth.Â  He then tied it behind her
  head and instructed her to put her hands behind her back and tied her hands.Â 
  He also tied her ankles together.Â  He asked Lemon if she had any money and told
  her he might have to cut her if she lied.Â  About that time, Lemon heard someone
  at the door.Â  Lemon heard the intruder running and called out to her boyfriend
  to warn him.Â  After she was able to free herself, she ran into the kitchen, and
  saw her boyfriend chasing the man around the corner of the building.
Shackett
  testified he arrived at the apartment he shared with Lemon at about 11:25.Â 
  When he opened the screen door, he noticed the main door was open and realized
  something was not right.Â  Suddenly, the door jerked open and he saw a black
  male standing in the doorway.Â  Shackett grabbed the man, and the intruder
  pushed Shackett to the side and began running.Â  Shackett gave chase, but was
  unable to keep up with the intruder.  
Lemon
  described the intruder to police as a light-skinned black man with short hair,
  between twenty and thirty years old, weighing around one hundred and
  seventy-five pounds and about five-nine or five-ten in height.Â  The day after
  the incident, Lemon and Shackett went to the police station and helped put
  together a composite by use of an identi-kit.[2] Â They were not satisfied with the results of that composite, and later met with
  a sketch artist and put a new composite together.Â  Both Lemon and Shackett felt
  the sketch artistâ€™s composite looked very similar to the intruder.  
Four
  or five nights after the incident, Lemon and Shackett were shown two different
  photo lineups.Â  Lemon was unable to identify anyone from the first lineup.Â  In
  the second one, she indicated one of the individuals looked more similar than
  any of the others, but she was not able to make a positive identification. Â Shackett
  likewise picked one individual from one of the lineups as looking similar to
  the intruder, but was not sure.Â  Both Lemon and Shackett had pointed out the
  same person
Using
  the sketch artistâ€™s composite, the police began a surveillance of the area near
  Lemonâ€™s apartment.Â  On the evening of June 24, officers observed a black male who
  looked just like the composite walking in the area.Â  That person was identified
  in court as Clark.Â  Clarkâ€™s picture was then placed in a third photographic lineup
  and was shown to both Lemon and Shackett. Â Lemon felt strongly that Clarkâ€™s picture looked like the suspect, but she could not be absolutely sure.Â  Lemon
  indicated she had seen the intruderâ€™s profile, and because it was dark and she
  had only seen his face for a few seconds, she felt she could better identify
  someone if she saw him in person.Â  However, the police informed her they could
  not do that.Â  When Shackett was shown the third lineup, he immediately picked
  out Clark as the intruder. Â He testified he had no doubt this was the person.Â 
  He then made an in-court identification of Clark as the intruder.Â   
Lemon
  testified she went to Clarkâ€™s bond hearing, and at that time she observed Clark facing exactly the way he was in her apartment.Â  She stated she was looking at the
  floor when she realized there was a man in shackles standing there.Â  When she
  looked up and saw him facing that way, a chill went over her, and she realized
  it was the intruder.Â  She testified she did not realize Clark would be at the bond
  hearing, and when she looked up and saw him, it caught her by surprise.Â  Lemon
  identified Clark in court as the person who was in her apartment that night. 
 
The
  evidence of record shows Clark was actually thirty-eight or thirty-nine years
  old, was about five feet five inches tall and weighed approximately one hundred
  and thirty-eight pounds.Â  The officer who arrested him testified, however, Clark did not look his age and he looked heavier than his actual weight.
On
  direct appeal, Clark argued the court erred in failing to suppress Lemonâ€™s
  in-court identification of him.Â  This court affirmed.
POST-CONVICTION RELIEF
In his hearing on the application for PCR, Clark argues defense
  counsel was ineffective at trial in failing to object to a portion of the solicitorâ€™s
  closing argument that allegedly vouched for and bolstered the credibility of
  the witnesses.
At trial, Lemon testified she â€œwas very hesitant to finger anyone
  because [she] saw [the perpetrator] so briefly and [she] wanted to be
  absolutely sure. . . .â€Â  Lemon believed if she saw the perpetrator in person
  and could see a profile, she would be able to state with certainty if the
  suspect was the perpetrator.Â  She requested an in-person lineup, stating she
  â€œcertainly didnâ€™t want to pick someone who was not the man.â€Â  On
  cross-examination, she repeated that she wanted to see the men in the photo
  lineups in person as she â€œdidnâ€™t feel good about fingering anybodyâ€ and
  â€œwhenever [she] was shown a lineup, [she] did not feel comfortable saying
  absolutely sure that it was anyone in those pictures because [she] wanted to be
  absolutely sure.â€Â  Lemon further testified:Â  â€œI remember thinking all at the
  same time I certainly donâ€™t want someone innocent to be charged with this
  crime.â€Â  At the bond hearing, Lemon witnessed Clark â€œfacing exactly the same
  way he was in [the] apartment.â€Â  She identified Clark.Â  Shackett likewise
  explained his hesitancy about identifying someone if he was not certain,
  testifying:Â  â€œ[O]f course, I donâ€™t want any innocent person being accused. . .
  . if Iâ€™m not a hundred percent sure, . . . I canâ€™t pick one out.â€Â   

	During closing
  arguments, the solicitor stated:
	
		Websterâ€™s
  dictionary defines reliability as the ability to rely on or to depend on.Â  In
  this case you had an opportunity to see the definition of the reliability from
  the witness stand with two people, Cosette Lemon and Terry Shackett.Â  Those two
  people told you time and time again, as did the police officers who met with
  them, that from the beginning of this case to the very end they said, I donâ€™t
  want to pick the wrong guy, I want to be careful, I want to make sure an
  innocent man is not arrested for this charge.Â  Over and over and over.Â  They
    were fearful.Â  They were careful.Â  They were dependable.Â  They were real.Â  They
    were honest.Â  And, again, in this courtroom yesterday they did all of those
  same things and you had an opportunity to see the definition of the reliability
  from that witness stand.Â  
	

(emphasis added).Â  Trial
  counsel did not object.Â   
At
  the PCR hearing, trial counsel, the PCR judge, and the assistant attorney
  general all conceded that stating the two witnesses were honest was the
  improper opinion of the solicitor.Â  Ultimately, however, the PCR judge found: Â â€œ[w]hile
  the statement that â€˜they were honestâ€™ could be construed as vouching for the
  credibility of the witnesses, such a statement also could be reasonably
  construed as highlighting the good-faith effort during the identification
  processâ€”an effort about which the witnesses themselves had testified.â€ Â Accordingly,
  the PCR judge denied Clarkâ€™s claim for ineffective assistance of counsel. Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The appellate court gives great deference to the post-conviction relief courtâ€™s findings of fact and
  conclusions of law.Â  Dempsey v. State, 363 S.C. 365, 368-69, 610 S.E.2d
  812, 814 (2005). Â On review, a
  PCR judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld if there is any evidence of probative value
  sufficient to support them. Â Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386
  S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989).Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
In
  order to establish a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, a PCR
  applicant must prove that: Â (1) counselâ€™s performance was deficient, and (2)
  the deficient performance prejudiced the applicantâ€™s case.Â  Id. Â To show
  that counsel was deficient, the applicant must establish that counsel failed to
  render reasonably effective assistance under prevailing professional norms.Â  Id.Â  To show prejudice, the applicant must show that but for counselâ€™s errors, there
  is a reasonable probability the result of the trial would have been different. Â Johnson
    v. State, 325 S.C. 182, 186, 480 S.E.2d 733, 735 (1997).Â  A reasonable
  probability is a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome
  of trial.Â  Id.
During trial, a
  solicitor â€œcannot vouch for the credibility of a witness by expressing or
  implying his personal opinion concerning a witnessâ€™ truthfulness.â€Â  State v.
    Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 630, 545 S.E.2d 805, 818 (2001).Â  Additionally, â€œ[i]t is inappropriate for the State to assure the jury
  of a witnessâ€™ credibility, because the jury is charged with assessing the
  credibility of witnesses based on evidence in the record.â€Â  Matthews v.
    State, 350 S.C. 272, 276, 565 S.E.2d 766, 768 (2002).  
We find even if
  Clarkâ€™s counsel was ineffective in failing to object to the solicitorâ€™s
  comments, there is no reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict would have been
  different and therefore there is no prejudice to Clark.Â  See Johnson,
  325 S.C. at 186, 480 S.E.2d at 735 (finding no prejudice where the result of
  the trial would not likely have been different).Â  Standing alone, the statement,
  â€œ[t]hey were honest,â€ could be inappropriate as vouching for the credibility of
  witnesses.Â  However, in this case, we agree with the PCR judgeâ€™s conclusion
  that the solicitorâ€™s comments were generally based on the witnessesâ€™ testimony,
  in which they described their concern about misidentifying the perpetrator.Â  The
  substance of the solicitorâ€™s closing argument reminded the jury of the

title: State v. Thurston
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDTIAL VALUE AND SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Michael Dean
      Thurston, Sr., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-429
Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  October 9, 2007Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster
				Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh
				Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott
				Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia, Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â Appellant appeals the trial courtâ€™s
  rulings that specific testimony given by two separate witnesses was relevant.
  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Appellant and
  Pamela Thurston were married, but the couple separated on April 30, 2004, when
  Appellant moved out.Â  On May 2, 2004, Appellant returned to the marital home,
  where Mrs. Thurston continued to reside, to retrieve some items he owned.Â 
  During Appellantâ€™s visit to the home, Mrs. Thurston called the police.Â 
  Appellant left the home by the time the responding officer arrived.Â   
The
  officer spoke with Mrs. Thurston and found her to be so nervous and upset that
  she was shaking.Â  Mrs. Thurston told the officer that while leaving, her
  husband told her he was going to kill her and then ran over the gate she was
  standing behind.Â  The officer inspected the metal gate and found it to be
  twisted.Â Â  The officer also spoke with Mrs. Thurstonâ€™s neighbor who claimed to
  have witnessed the events between Appellant and Mrs. Thurston.Â  The neighborâ€™s
  description of the events corroborated the description given by Mrs. Thurston.
Based
  on these events, Appellant was indicted for assault with intent to kill.Â 
  Appellant was convicted by a jury of the lesser offense of assault of a high and
  aggravated nature.Â  Appellant was sentenced to five years imprisonment.Â Â  
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ Â State
    v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001). Â â€œThe admission or exclusion of evidence is a matter
  within the sound discretion of the trial court and absent clear abuse, will not
  be disturbed on appeal.â€ Â Gamble v. Int'l Paper Realty Corp. of S.C.,
  323 S.C. 367, 373, 474 S.E.2d 438, 441 (1996). Â â€œAn abuse of discretion
  occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.â€Â  State v.
    Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 566, 598 S.E.2d 279, 285 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  To
  warrant reversal, an appellant must show both error and resulting prejudice. Â Recco Tape & Label
    Co., Inc. v. Barfield, 312 S.C. 214, 216, 439 S.E.2d 838, 840 (1994). Â The
  determination of the prejudicial effect of the evidence must be based on the
  entire record and the result will generally turn on the facts of each case.Â  State
    v. Gillian, 373 S.C. 601, 609, 646 S.E.2d 872, 876 (2007).
LAW/ANALYSIS
â€œRelevant
  evidence means evidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact
  that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less
  probable than it would be without the evidence.â€ Rule 401, SCRE. â€œ[E]vidence is relevant if it has a direct bearing
  upon and tends to establish or make more or less probable the matter in
  controversy.â€ State v. Staten, 364 S.C. 7, 36-37, 610 S.E.2d 823, 838
  (Ct. App. 2005).
Appellant appeals the trial courtâ€™s rulings that
  specific testimony given by two separate witnesses was relevant.Â Â   
I.  Mrs. Thurstonâ€™s
  Testimony
During the solicitorâ€™s direct examination of Mrs.
  Thurston, she stated she first saw Appellant on the morning of the assault when
  he woke her up.Â  The solicitor then asked Mrs. Thurston how the Appellant woke
  her up.Â  Mrs. Thurston responded: â€œI had a bunch of things piled in front of
  the door so I would be awoked [sic] because I was staying up all night because
  I was scared he would come in the middle of the night.â€Â  At this point,
  Appellantâ€™s trial attorney objected.Â   
Appellant contends
  this testimony was offered to imply Mrs. Thurston had reason to fear him.Â  In
  support of this contention, Appellant points out additional testimony given by
  Mrs. Thurston, which followed the response quoted above, in which she stated
  the Appellant came in â€˜ragingâ€ and â€œhollering different things.â€Â  Appellant
  also points out that the solicitor referred to him as a â€œbullyâ€ during his
  closing arguments.Â  However, Appellantâ€™s trial attorney failed to object to the
  additional testimony or the comments by the solicitor.Â  To properly preserve
  an issue for review there must be a contemporaneous objection that is ruled upon by the trial court.Â  State v. Johnson, 363
  S.C. 53, 58, 609 S.E.2d 520, 523 (2005).
  Accordingly, this additional testimony and the solicitorâ€™s comments are not
  preserved for review.  
The testimony that Appellant
  objected to explained how Mrs. Thurston first encountered the Appellant on the
  day of the assault.Â  Appellant had not been staying at the home since he and
  Mrs. Thurston separated.Â  Mrs. Thurston was explaining how Appellant, who did
  not live with her, was able to wake her up by entering her home.Â  She did not
  say she was scared of Appellant but that she â€œwas scared he would come in the middle of the night.â€Â  The trial
  court did not abuse its discretion in finding the evidence to be relevant.Â  The
  testimony, by explaining how Appellantâ€™s entry into Mrs. Thurstonâ€™s home had
  awakened her, makes it more probable that he was at her home on the day of the
  assault.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
II.  Appellantâ€™s Cross
  Examination
During his cross examination of Appellant, the
  solicitor asked Appellant: â€œTwo days before that on April 30th, you had thrown
  your wife around, hadnâ€™t you?â€Â  Appellant responded: â€œNo sir. We had got into
  an argument and I left.â€Â  After discussing Appellantâ€™s weight and stature and
  the weight of Mrs. Thurston, the solicitor states that he would like to talk
  about â€œthe argument on the 30th.â€Â  At this point, Appellantâ€™s trial attorney
  objected based on relevancy.Â  The trial court overruled the relevancy
  objection.Â   
There
  is no objection in the record to the specific questions or responses the Appellant
  now points out and takes exception with.Â  The only objection to the testimony
  came almost a full page in the record after Appellant first answered the
  solicitorâ€™s question about the alleged argument on April 30th and
  almost a full page before the solicitor asked the other questions now
  specifically pointed out by Appellant.Â  It is well settled
  that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been
  raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved.Â  Pye v. Estate
    of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 565, 633 S.E.2d 505, 510 (2006).Â 
  Furthermore, given that Appellant had already answered the solicitorâ€™s first
  questions well before Appellantâ€™s trial attorney objected, there was no
  prejudicial effect from similar questions asked and answered following the
  objection.Â  Accordingly, we find no error on the part of the trial court on
  this issue.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons
  stated above, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: SCDSS v. C.B.
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				South Carolina
      Department of Social Services, Respondent,
				v.
				C.B. and T.B., Appellants.
				In the Interest of:Â  I.B., Date of Birth
  04/23/05, a Minor Child Under the Age of 18.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lee County
Â Marion D. Myers, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-430
Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  9, 2007Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				James P. Saverance, Jr., of Bishopville, for Appellant T.B., and Charles
  Thomas Brooks, of Sumter, for Appellant C.B.
				Deborah Truett Nielsen, of Bishopville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  C.B. (Mother) and T.B. (Father) appeal from a family court order terminating
  their parental rights to I.B. (Daughter).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Daughter is Motherâ€™s seventh child and Fatherâ€™s twelfth.[2]Â  Mother does not have custody of any
  of her other children, and several of Fatherâ€™s children have been raised by
  relatives.Â   
The
  Department of Social Services (DSS) became involved in this case when Mother
  tested positive for cocaine and marijuana during her third trimester of
  pregnancy with Daughter.Â  DSS received a report about this drug use on March
  14, 2005, and the case was indicated on April 28, 2005 for substantial risk of
  physical abuse and neglect.Â  Daughter was born on April 23, 2005, and she was
  placed into DSS custody on June 1, 2005.Â   
Both Mother and Father have long histories of drug abuse.Â  In
  1995, Mother gave birth to a child who tested positive for cocaine, and in
  March 2000, Mother tested positive for cocaine while she was pregnant with
  another child.Â  At the termination of parental rights (TPR) hearing, DSS
  presented two experts - Sam Tipton, a drug and alcohol counselor, and Dr.
  Patrick Goldsmith, a psychologist.Â  Â Â 
Tipton diagnosed Mother as having cocaine dependence and cannabis dependence.Â 
  Tipton testified that, although Mother did â€œreal wellâ€ in treatment initially,
  she relapsed within a week after participating in a program in 2005 at The
  Palmetto Center, an inpatient treatment facility.Â  Mother was tested for drugs a
  few months later in early 2006, and she again tested positive for cocaine on
  two occasions.Â  Mother was tested in August 2006 and when that test came back
  positive, Mother was sent to The Charleston Center, another inpatient program.Â  
 
Dr. Goldsmith testified he met with Mother in July 2005 and
  administered several psychological tests to her.Â  Based on these tests, he
  diagnosed her with cannabis dependency, cocaine dependency, and severe mental
  retardation.Â  He also found she had multiple stressors associated with
  addiction and mental retardation.Â  Motherâ€™s overall IQ was below 35, which is
  in the severe range of mental retardation.Â  Dr. Goldsmith opined that â€œshe will
  need assistance most of her life, and that generally is not reversible.Â  She
  might have some mental improvement if she would stop using drugs; but, I doubt
  . . . her sincerity in regard to that.â€Â  Dr. Goldsmith described Motherâ€™s
  addiction as being â€œas severe as anything [heâ€™d] ever seenâ€ and explained that
  â€œher failed drug screens while pregnant and after removal are indicative of
  severity.â€Â   
Dr. Goldsmith also met with Father during
  July 2005.Â  He diagnosed Father with schizophrenia, dementia due to alcoholism,
  and as having severe stressors due to his complicated psychiatric problems and
  marital difficulties.Â  Dr. Goldsmith noted Fatherâ€™s addiction to alcohol was in
  remission, but that he suffered permanent damage from his previous alcohol
  abuse.Â  He stated Father reads at a second-grade level and cannot remember
  three items after five minutes.Â  Dr. Goldsmith also noted Father was on disability
  and had a guardian appointed to handle his disability fund.Â  Â Â 
Melissa Robinson, the foster care worker for Daughter, also
  testified at the TPR hearing.Â  Robinson acknowledged that both Mother and Father
  consistently visited Daughter and brought her clothes or other items when they
  came to visit.Â  Robinson stated that, although DSS currently had no prospective
  adoptive parents for Daughter, she was â€œdoing greatâ€ in her foster home.Â 
  Robinson testified Mother did not complete her treatment plan, but Father had essentially
  done everything DSS had asked of him.Â  Despite Fatherâ€™s compliance with the
  treatment plan, however, Robinson did not believe Father was able to care for
  Daughter by himself, nor did she know of any relatives who could help care for
  the child.Â  Robinson noted that DSS performed a home study on one of Fatherâ€™s
  sisters, but DSS declined to place Daughter with the sister because she had
  been convicted of criminal domestic violence.Â   
The guardian ad litem filed a report with the family court
  recommending the termination of both Motherâ€™s and Fatherâ€™s parental rights.Â  In
  the report, the guardian noted she would rather see Daughter placed with a
  relative who knew the childâ€™s limitations, but the only relative who wanted the
  child was not acceptable to DSS because of her prior conviction.Â  At the TPR
  hearing, the guardian expressed her reluctance to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental
  rights, but ultimately stood by the recommendation in her report.Â   
The family court found Mother had a diagnosable condition that was
  unlikely to change within a reasonable time; she failed to remedy conditions
  leading to Daughterâ€™s removal; and, due to the severity and repetition of
  Motherâ€™s abuse and neglect, it was unlikely her home could be made safe within
  the next twelve months.Â  With regard to Father, the family court found he had a
  diagnosable condition that was unlikely to change within a reasonable time and
  that, because of the diagnosable condition, he had failed to remedy conditions
  leading to Daughterâ€™s removal.Â  The family court further found termination of
  Motherâ€™s and Fatherâ€™s parental rights was in Daughterâ€™s best interest.Â  Mother
  and Father have filed separate appeals.
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
In a TPR action, the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Doe
    v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 578 S.E.2d 733 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before
  parental rights may be irrevocably terminated, the State must prove the alleged
  grounds for termination by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Richberg v.
    Dawson, 278 S.C. 356, 296 S.E.2d 338 (1982); South Carolina Depâ€™t
      of Soc. Servs. V. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 519 S.E.2d 351 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
 
On appeal in a TPR action, an appellate court has the authority to
  review the entire record to make its own factual findings and to determine whether
  the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 547 S.E.2d 506
  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  This broad scope of review, however, does not require the
  appellate court to disregard the findings of the family court, which was in a
  better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and to assign comparative
  weight to their testimony.Â  Hardy v. Gunter, 353 S.C. 128, 577 S.E.2d
  231 (Ct. App. 2003).Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Expert
  Testimony
Mother initially argues the family court erred in qualifying Sam
  Tipton as an expert witness and in attaching any weight to his testimony.Â  We
  disagree.
â€œTo qualify as an expert, a person must have acquired by study or
  practical experience a special knowledge of a subject matter about which the
  [fact-finderâ€™s] good judgment and average knowledge is inadequate.â€Â  Manning
    v. City of Columbia, 297 S.C. 451, 453-54, 377 S.E.2d 335, 337 (1989).Â  The
  qualification of expert witnesses and the admissibility of their opinions are
  matters resting within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Id. at 453, 377 S.E.2d at 336-37.Â  On appeal, we will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s
  ruling in the absence of an abuse of that discretion and a showing of
  prejudice.Â  Strange v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Hwys. & Pub. Transp.,
  307 S.C. 161, 414 S.E.2d 138 (1992).
Before being qualified as an expert in addiction counseling,
  Tipton testified that he had been employed as a drug and alcohol abuse
  counselor for approximately seven years.Â  To become a counselor, Tipton had to
  complete four years of college and receive certification from the State.Â 
  Although Tipton does not regularly testify in court, he was qualified as an
  expert in another court proceeding several years prior to the TPR hearing in
  this case.Â  Based on Tiptonâ€™s experience, education, and training, we find the
  family court did not abuse its discretion in qualifying Tipton as an expert in
  addiction counseling.
II. Grounds
  for Termination
Next, both Mother and Father appeal from the family courtâ€™s
  finding that grounds exist to terminate their parental rights.Â  Addressing
  Motherâ€™s arguments first, she contends the record does not contain clear and
  convincing evidence that she has a diagnosable condition that is unlikely to
  change within a reasonable time.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-1572(6) of the South Carolina Code provides in
  relevant part as follows:

	It is presumed that the parentâ€™s condition is unlikely to change
  within a reasonable time upon proof that the parent has been required by the
  department or the family court to participate in a treatment program for
  alcohol or drug addiction, and the parent has failed two or more times to
  complete the program successfully or has refused at two or more separate
  meetings with the department to participate in a treatment program[.]

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-7-1572(6) (Supp. 2006).
Here,
  Mother received inpatient treatment at The Palmetto Center, and she relapsed within
  a week of being released to after-care services.Â  Mother continued to test
  positive for cocaine until August 18, 2006, two months prior to the TPR
  hearing.Â  DSS again referred Mother for inpatient treatment, which was supposed
  to last for three months, but Mother was discharged with a month.[3]Â  On October 6, 2006, just days before
  the TPR hearing, Mother missed her scheduled appointment at another drug
  rehabilitation center.Â   
In addition to the failed treatments during the pendency of this
  action, Mother has a long history of abusing drugs and being unable to overcome
  her addiction, even while pregnant or facing the termination of her parental
  rights.Â  DSS presented evidence that Mother used cocaine during two previous pregnancies.Â 
  Accordingly, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s determination that Mother
  has a diagnosable condition that is unlikely to change within a reasonable
  time.[4]
Likewise, Father contends the family court erred in finding he had
  a diagnosable condition unlikely to change within a reasonable time.Â  Specifically,
  he argues he has the mental capacity and ability to provide minimally
  acceptable care for Daughter.Â  We disagree.
According to testimony presented at the TPR hearing, Father has a
  full- scale IQ of 50.Â  Dr. Goldsmith testified Father reads at a second-grade
  level and could not remember a list of three items after five minutes.Â  In
  addition to these problems, Father has been diagnosed with schizophrenia and
  dementia due to alcoholism.Â   
Father is to be commended for complying with his treatment plan;
  however, his intellectual functioning is unfortunately so impaired that neither
  Dr. Goldsmith nor Melissa Robinson, the foster care worker, believed Father
  could parent Daughter.Â  Although the guardian initially expressed feeling
  â€œconflictedâ€ about recommending the termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights,
  the family court, which actually saw and heard Father testify at the hearing,
  found the evidence â€œoverwhelmingly clear and convincingâ€ and stated it had â€œno
  doubt . . . that neither of [Daughterâ€™s] two biological parents . . . are fit
  and proper individuals to have custody of [Daughter].â€Â  See Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 477 S.E.2d
  476 (Ct. App. 1996) (explaining that despite the appellate courtâ€™s broad scope
  of review, it should remain cognizant that the family court had the advantage
  of seeing and hearing the witnesses before making findings of fact).Â  We find
  clear and convincing evidence was presented to prove Father suffers from a
  diagnosable condition that is unlikely to change within a reasonable time.
II. Best
  Interest
Finally,
  Mother and Father argue terminating their parental rights would not serve
  Daughterâ€™s best interest.Â  We disagree.
At the
  time of the TPR hearing, Daughter was eighteen months old, and she had been in
  foster care for all but one month of her life.Â  Although Mother and Father
  visited frequently, the guardian testified that any harm to Daughter if her
  biological parentsâ€™ rights were terminated would be â€œshort-termâ€ as children â€œrebound
  very quickly.â€Â  Furthermore, there was evidence Daughter was doing well in
  foster care, and at least one potential adoptive family became disinterested
  upon learning Daughter was not yet free for adoption.Â  Considering Daughterâ€™s
  young age and the improbability that either Mother or Father would ever be able
  to care for her, we agree a long-term plan of adoption is in Daughterâ€™s best
  interest.
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, the order of the family court terminating Motherâ€™s and
  Fatherâ€™s parental rights is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  At the time of the hearing in this matter, Mother
  was pregnant again.Â   
[3]Â  It is unclear from the record why Mother was
  discharged, but Mother offered no proof that she had successfully completed the
  program.
[4] Â Having found this statutory ground established by
  clear and convincing evidence, we need not address the remaining grounds relied
  upon by the family court.
