title: SCDSS v. Mother
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR
  RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				South Carolina
      Department of Social Services, Respondent,
				v.
				Father A, Mother,
      Father B, and Child 1Â  05/09/92,Â  and Child 2Â  06/05/93, Defendants, 
				
				of whom Mother
          is Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â F. P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion 2007-UP-431
Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  9, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				James K. Holmes, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Paul C. White, of Moncks Corner, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Mother
  appeals the termination of her parental rights (TPR) to her two minor children.Â 
  Â Â We affirm.[1]Â   
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On November 24, 1999, the two minor children were placed in
  protective custody based on allegations that Mother posed a threat of harm to
  the minor children.Â  Father A, Motherâ€™s husband and the father of one of the
  minor children, had been accused of sexually molesting two other children.Â  After
  a hearing on November 29, 1999, the family court found the Department of Social
  Services (DSS) had probable cause to assume protective custody of the children;
  however, the court returned legal and physical custody to Mother because Father
  A had removed himself from the home.Â   
The merits hearing was rescheduled three times and finally heard
  on June 1, 2001.Â  At the hearing, the family court found Mother posed a risk of
  harm to the minor children, but allowed her to retain custody subject to a
  restraining order that Father A not be left alone with the children.Â  Both
  Mother and Father A were ordered to attend individual and family counseling.Â  
 
DSS commenced another removal case on August 16, 2001, alleging that,
  on August 11, 2001, Father A attempted to sexually abuse a visiting niece when
  he was left alone with the children in violation of the restraining order.Â  The
  family court issued an order placing the minor children in protective custody.Â 
  The merits hearing on the second removal action was scheduled for September 17,
  2001, but was continued because insufficient time had been scheduled for a
  contested hearing.Â  The hearing was continued again on February 27, 2002, for
  the same reason.Â  On April 4, 2002, the family court ordered the case to be
  immediately set for a two-day trial.Â  When no hearing was scheduled, Mother
  filed a motion to dismiss.Â  A hearing on that motion was not scheduled, and
  Mother filed a second motion, requesting an expedited hearing on her motion to dismiss.Â 
  A hearing on Motherâ€™s motion was held on April 24, 2003.Â  By order dated May
  21, 2003, and filed May 28, 2003, the family court noted new counsel had been
  appointed to represent Mother and ordered the cases to be heard within thirty
  days or the minor children returned to Mother without a further hearing.Â  Â Â 
While the matter was under advisement, however, a merits hearing
  on the second removal action was held on May 19 and 20, 2003.Â  The family court
  found DSS failed to prove Mother left the children unattended with Father A on
  August, 11, 2001, but did find that Mother had left the children alone with Father
  A at some unspecified time.Â  By order dated June 23, 2003, and filed June 25,
  2003, the family court granted DSS physical and legal custody of the children
  based on a threat of harm. Â Attached to the order was a treatment plan
  acknowledging Mother had completed parenting classes and requiring her to complete
  a mental health assessment, follow the recommendations of the therapist,
  participate in family therapy with the children, support the children, and
  provide a safe home for the children. 
A permanency planning hearing was held on June 5, 2003.Â  By order
  filed July 25, 2003, the family court found, in relevant part, a hearing to
  determine whether the children should be returned to Mother must be held within
  six months.Â  A supplemental order, which was referred to as a treatment plan,
  was attached.Â  This treatment plan acknowledged (1) Mother had completed
  parenting classes; (2) Mother had participated in family therapy until August
  13, 2002, when there was a â€œcrisisâ€ involving the police that resulted in the
  cessation of her participation in family therapy; and (3) Motherâ€™s visitation
  rights had been temporarily suspended in April 2003.Â  This treatment plan also
  required Mother to obtain a mental health assessment, follow the recommendations
  of the therapist performing the assessment, and support the children.Â  Finally,
  under the treatment plan, Mother was to have supervised visitation with the
  children.Â  The plan also called for Mother to attend family therapy with one of
  the children so that the two could address certain issues concerning that child
  and complete â€œclarification.â€Â  
Mother filed a motion to alter or amend the permanency planning order
  on August 13, 2003.Â  By order filed November 26, 2003, the family court amended
  the order and required counsel for DSS to â€œsubmit an agreement to this Court
  which states only those items that Defendants are required to do in terms of
  the treatment/placement plans.â€Â  DSS did not submit an agreed-upon treatment
  plan, however, and no hearing was scheduled within six months as the family
  court directed in its July 25, 2003 order.Â  Furthermore, Mother argues on
  appeal she was not granted supervised visitation in a timely manner.
A second permanency planning hearing was scheduled for July 26,
  2004.Â  This hearing was rescheduled twice because insufficient time was
  allotted for a contested hearing.Â  On December 12, 2005, the third time the
  hearing was scheduled, the family court continued the case yet again to January
  23, 2006, this time pursuant to a motion by the guardian ad litem on the ground that Father B, the biological father of one of the minor
  children, had not been served.Â  In the order of continuance, the family court
  also noted DSS had not followed the statutory guidelines for moving the case
  forward in a timely fashion, substantially affecting Motherâ€™s constitutional
  rights and stated the children would be returned to Mother if DSS failed to
  effect service â€œabsent good causeâ€ in time for the hearing to proceed on
  January 23, 2006.[2]Â   
The second permanency planning hearing was held on January 23-24,
  2006.Â  By order filed on April 5, 2006, the family court terminated Motherâ€™s
  parental rights.Â  On April 24, 2006, Mother filed a motion to alter or amend
  the judgment or, in the alternative, for a new trial or relief from the judgment.Â 
  By order filed on July 26, 2006, the family court denied the requested relief.Â 
  This appeal followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section
  20-7-1578 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006), mandates that the TPR
  statutes â€œmust be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial
  procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and control of their
  parents by terminating the parent-child relationship.â€Â  See also Joiner
    v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 109, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 (2000) (overruling prior
  cases calling for strict construction of the TPR statutes).Â   
Grounds
  for TPR must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc.
    Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 608-09, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003) (citing Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982)).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[u]pon review,
  the appellate court may make its own finding from the record as to whether
  clear and convincing evidence supports the termination.â€Â  Id. at 609,
  582 S.E.2d at 423.Â  The reviewing court, however, is not required â€œto ignore
  the fact that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a
  better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to
  their testimony.â€Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d
  358, 367 (1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Mother contends the
  family court erred in failing to return the children when DSS failed to comply
  with the terms of the December 12, 2005 order issued by the family court.Â  We find
  no error. Â 
In its final order,
  the family court found DSS was â€œin substantial compliance with said order as it
  was verbally issued from the bench.â€Â  We agree.Â  The December 12, 2005 order
  mandated return of the children to Mother only if DSS failed to effect timely
  service â€œabsent good cause.â€Â  Father B, the particular defendant for whom service
  was at issue, had already voluntarily relinquished his parental rights.Â 
  According to counsel for DSS, he was served December 29, 2005.Â  There is no
  evidence that the failure to DSS to effect service in time for the hearing to
  proceed was without good cause.Â  Moreover, the hearing proceeded as scheduled
  and the family court issued a final order in the matter.Â  Accordingly, although
  DSS did not strictly comply with the order of December 12, 2005, we affirm the
  family courtâ€™s refusal to return the children to Mother on this ground.
2.Â  On appeal, Mother
  challenges each of the grounds cited by the family court to support its
  decision to terminate her parental rights.[3]Â 
  Because we affirm the family courtâ€™s determinations regarding Motherâ€™s failure
  to provide material support to the children while they were foster care, we
  hold DSS established at least one basis for termination of her parental
  rights.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2006) (â€œThe family court
  may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more
    of the following grounds . . . .â€) (emphasis added).
One statutory ground
  for termination of parental rights is a finding by the family court that â€œ[t]he
  child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months,
  and during that time the parent has willfully failed to support the child.â€Â  Id. Â§ 20-7-1572(4).Â  â€œFailure to support means that the parent has failed to make a
  material contribution to the childâ€™s care.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œA material
  contribution consists of either financial contributions according to the
  parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other
  necessities according to the parentâ€™s means.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œJust as it does in determining wilful failure to visit, the family
  court has wide discretion in determining whether a failure to support is
  wilful.â€Â  Headden, 354 S.C. at 612, 582 S.E.2d at 425.Â  Moreover, the
  family court may â€œlook beyond the months immediately preceding the TPR actionâ€
  at a parentâ€™s â€œoverall conduct.â€Â  Id. (emphasis in original).
Mother paid $304.00
  in five payments over the fifty-three months the children were in foster care;
  however, she paid no money at all during 2002 or 2003.Â  Although a caseworker
  acknowledged Mother at times brought the children lunch and gave them clothing
  and undergarments, the tenor of the case workerâ€™s testimony was that these
  in-kind contributions did not evidence any appreciable effort on Motherâ€™s part
  to provide for her children.Â   
On appeal, Mother
  cites evidence that her caseworkers were aware she was unemployed.Â  We find it significant,
  however, that, the treatment plan called for Mother to support the children and
  Mother herself moved to have her court-ordered child support set at $40.00 per
  month.Â  Furthermore, although Mother claimed she had made good-faith efforts to
  find work but had not received offers of employment because of criminal changes
  pending against her and Father A, she never submitted concrete, specific
  evidence regarding her endeavors.Â  We therefore hold the record supports the
  family courtâ€™s finding that Mother did not provide material support to the
  children according to her means while they were in the custody of DSS.  
3.Â  Mother further contends the
  termination of her parental rights was improper because the family court erred
  in finding the termination was in the best interests of the children.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
The paramount
  consideration in any case involving a termination of parental rights is the
  best interests of the children.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Vanderhorst,
  287 S.C. 554, 561, 340 S.E.2d 149, 153 (1986).Â  â€œThe interests of the child
  shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2006).
One
  of the caseworkers testified that, notwithstanding the disruption in the
  childrenâ€™s lives from the litigation and their entry into the foster care
  system, their lives have become more stable during the time they have been in
  the custody of DSS.Â  The caseworker further expressed concern that Mother had
  not indicated any willingness to understand the risk the children would face if
  Father A had access to them.Â  The guardian ad litem expressed a
  similar concern as well as her opinion that visits between Mother and the
  children led to mixed feelings and confusion for the children.Â  In view of this
  testimony, we hold the family court correctly determined that termination of Motherâ€™s
  parental rights was in the childrenâ€™s best interest.
4.Â  Although
  we have affirmed the termination of parental rights in this case, we commend the
  numerous attorneys who represented Mother, most if not all of whom were
  court-appointed counsel, for their zealous and thorough advocacy on their
  clientâ€™s behalf during this prolonged and emotionally difficult litigation.
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
  KITTREDGE, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] For unknown reasons, this order was not filed until
  January 23, 2006, the same day as the hearing.Â   
[3]Â  The family court based its decision to terminate
  Motherâ€™s parental rights on (1) Motherâ€™s failure to provide material support to
  the children while they were in the custody of DSS; (2) the length of time the
  children had been in foster care; and (3) Motherâ€™s failure to remedy the
  condition causing the removal of the children or to otherwise rehabilitate
  herself and the uncertainty that Mother could provide a safe home for the
  children within twelve months.Â

title: Harvey v. Chapman Mirror & Glass
text:
THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Zachary Harvey, Respondent,
				v.
				Chapman Mirror
      & Glass and RSRJ, LLC, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-440
Submitted September 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  October 9, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				David Alexander and Cecil H. Nelson, Jr., both of Greenville, for Appellants.
				Brian Patrick Murphy, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM: Chapman
  Mirror and Glass and RSRJ, LLC (collectively Appellants), appeal the jury
  verdict in favor of Zachary Harvey (Harvey) claiming: (1) the trial court erred
  in not granting Appellantsâ€™ judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV) motion;
  (2) the trial court failed to adequately charge the jury on the requirements
  necessary to modify a written contract; and (3) the evidence at trial was
  legally insufficient to sustain an award of punitive damages.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Appellant RSRJ,
  LLC, a North Carolina company, operates Chapman Mirror and Glass (Chapman).Â 
  Randall Simmons and Roland Johnson formed RSRJ for the purpose of purchasing
  Chapman.Â  Chapman supplies and installs â€œafter paintâ€ products, which include
  shower doors, mirrors, closet shelving, and bath and door hardware.Â   
In April 2003,
  Chapman hired Harvey as a sales representative at its Greenville, South Carolina branch.Â  Harvey was assigned a sales territory and made sales calls to
  Chapman customers.Â  During the interview process, Harvey was given a copy of
  Chapmanâ€™s Sales Employment Agreement (the Agreement).Â  The Agreement governed
  the terms of Harveyâ€™s employment and included a covenant not to compete.Â  Harvey signed the Agreement on April 10, 2003.Â 
 
In late 2004,
  Roland Johnson divorced his wife, Annette Johnson.Â  In the divorce settlement,
  Mrs. Johnson acquired her husbandâ€™s membership interest in RSRJ.Â  Mrs. Johnson
  and Simmons did not agree on the management of the business and began
  negotiating a buy out by one of the parties.Â  Mrs. Johnson and her accountant
  visited the Greenville branch as part of her review of the business and its
  assets. Â Prior to the visit, the office manager, Marty Street, told the
  employees at the Greenville branch that he worried Mrs. Johnson planned to take
  a more active role in the business, and he did not want to work for a woman.Â 
  Street shredded the Agreements in his possession before Mrs. Johnsonâ€™s visit to
  Greenville and informed Harvey he had done so.Â  Ultimately, Simmons bought out
  Mrs. Johnsonâ€™s interest in the business.Â   
In April 2005, Gale
  Contractor Services (Gale), a competitor of Chapman, recruited Harvey.Â  Based on prior conversations, Harvey testified he was under the impression he was
  no longer constrained by the Agreement and the covenant not to compete.Â  As
  such, Harvey accepted the employment offer with Gale.Â  Harvey informed Street
  he was resigning and was accepting a sales position with Gale.Â  Street and
  Simmons unsuccessfully tried to convince Harvey to stay at Chapman.Â  Harvey worked the final two weeks of April without incident.Â 
 
Harvey contends,
  once he gave his two week notice, Street and Simmons never indicated to him
  that his working for Gale was a breach of any existing contractual agreement.Â 
  He further recalled an instance in which Simmons brought up the torn Agreements
  and represented to Harvey he would not pursue the matter.Â  Appellants contend Harvey tried to convince Street he would not be competing with Chapman and he would be in a
  management training program at Gale.Â  Further, Simmons claims he told Harvey if he pursued Chapmanâ€™s customers, Chapman would enforce the covenant not to
  compete.Â   
Harvey began
  working at Gale on May 2, 2005.Â  On May 10, 2005, Chapmanâ€™s attorney sent a
  letter to Steven Click, Galeâ€™s general manager, asserting Harvey was bound to a
  non-compete agreement with Chapman, and Chapman would commence a lawsuit if
  Harveyâ€™s employment was not immediately terminated.Â  A similar letter was sent
  directly to Harvey.Â  As a result of the letter, Click terminated Harvey on May 18, 2005.
On May 24, 2005, Harvey filed a complaint
  and an amended complaint on May 2, 2006, alleging, inter alia, Chapmanâ€™s
  intentional interference with a contract, negligent misrepresentation,
  constructive fraud, promissory estoppel, and breach of contract.Â  A jury trial
  was held on June 5, 6, and 7, 2006.Â  The trial judge submitted to the jury the
  claims for (1) intentional interference with contract, (2) negligent
  misrepresentation, and (3) constructive fraud.Â  The parties consented to a
  general verdict form.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of Harvey in the total amount of $175,000, consisting of $75,000 in actual damages and
  $100,000 in punitive damages.Â  Appellants moved for JNOV, which the trial judge
  denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  JNOV
Appellants claim the trial court erred in not granting
  their JNOV motion because Harvey presented no evidence of any consideration or
  meeting of the minds to support a modification of the contract.Â  Harvey avers the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule applies, such that this Court need not address the issues
  raised involving modification.Â  We agree with Harvey.  
Pursuant
  to the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule, when a jury returns a general verdict involving two or
  more issues, and its verdict is supported by at least one issue, the appellate
  court will affirm unless the appellant appeals all causes of action.Â  Anderson v. S.C. Dept. of Highways and Pub. Transp., 322 S.C. 417, 419-20,
  472 S.E.2d 253, 254 (1996).Â   
By
  agreement, this case was submitted for a general verdict on three claims: (1)
  intentional interference with a contract; (2) negligent misrepresentation; and
  (3) constructive fraud.Â  The trial court charged the jury on all three claims.Â 
  Harvey contends Appellantsâ€™ arguments on appeal regarding modification relate
  solely to the intentional interference with a contract claim, and therefore,
  they have not appealed the negligent misrepresentation or constructive fraud
  claims.Â  Further, Harvey claims the two
  non-appealed claims support the jury verdict.Â  Conversely, Appellants contend
  the alleged lack of modification relates to all three claims, and therefore,
  the judgment must be reversed.Â   
We
  find the issue of modification, raised by Appellants, relates to the
  intentional interference with a contract claim.Â  Specifically, modification
  relates to the fourth element of the claim, the absence of justification.Â  To
  establish intentional interference with a contract one must show (1) the
  existence of the contract; (2) the other partyâ€™s knowledge of its existence;
  (3) the other partyâ€™s intentional procurement of the breach of the contract;
  (4) the absence of justification; and (5) resulting damage.Â  Webb v. Elrod,
  308 S.C. 445, 447, 418 S.E.2d 559, 561 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Appellants claim there
  was no modification of the Agreement, and thus, the covenant not to compete was
  still in force when Harvey left Chapman.Â  According to Appellants, Simmons
  acted within his contractual rights when he enforced the terms of the covenant
  not to compete.Â  We agree Appellantsâ€™ argument on modification applies to the
  intentional interference claim, such that a lack of modification may serve as
  justification for Simmonsâ€™ actions.
However,
  we fail to see how Appellantsâ€™ modification argument relates to either the
  negligent misrepresentation or constructive fraud claims.Â  In a negligent
  misrepresentation action, a plaintiff must prove the following: (1) the
  defendant made a false representation to the plaintiff; (2) the defendant had a
  pecuniary interest in making the statement; (3) the defendant owed a duty of
  care to see that he communicated truthful information to the plaintiff; (4) the
  defendant breached that duty by failing to exercise due care; (5) the plaintiff
  justifiably relied on the representation; and (6) the plaintiff suffered a
  pecuniary loss as a proximate result of his reliance on the representation.Â  Armstrong
    v. Collins, 366 S.C. 204, 219-20, 621 S.E.2d 368, 375 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
 
To
  establish constructive fraud, all elements of actual fraud except the element
  of intent must be established.Â  Pitts v. Jackson Natâ€™l Life Ins. Co.,
  352 S.C. 319, 333, 574 S.E.2d 502, 509 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  To sustain a claim of
  actual fraud, the following elements must be proven: (1) a representation; (2)
  its falsity; (3) its materiality; (4) either knowledge of its falsity or
  reckless disregard of its truth or falsity; (5) intent that the representation
  be acted upon; (6) the hearerâ€™s ignorance of its falsity; (7) the hearerâ€™s
  reliance on its truth; (8) the hearerâ€™s right to rely thereon; and (9) the
  hearerâ€™s consequent and proximate injury.Â  Armstrong, 366 S.C. at 218,
  621 S.E.2d at 375.Â   
Appellants
  argue modification relates to these two claims because if Simmons acted within
  his contractual rights, then he made no misrepresentation and could not have
  committed fraud.Â  Regardless of whether Simmons was acting within his
  contractual rights, Harvey presented evidence of misrepresentations made by
  Simmons and Street.Â  After Harvey informed Simmons and Street he was resigning
  and going to work for a competitor, Simmons and Street represented that Chapman
  would not pursue the matter.Â  If, as Appellants claim, Simmons had a contractual
  right to enforce the covenant not to compete, the jury could conclude that a
  representation to Harvey that Chapman would not pursue the matter is a
  misrepresentation.  
We
  find the jury returned a general verdict involving three causes of action, and
  Appellants have only appealed one cause.Â  Further, we find the verdict is supported
  by the constructive fraud claim.Â  Harvey presented evidence of the following:
  (1) a representation by Simmons that Chapman would not pursue the covenant not
  to compete; (2) Simmons knew his representation was false; (3) Simmons
  representation was material; (4) Simmons knew the falsity of his representation
  as evident from his actions to enforce the covenant not to compete less than
  ten days after Harvey left Chapman; (5) Harvey was ignorant of the falsity of
  the representation; (6) Harvey relied on the truth of the representation as
  evident from Harveyâ€™s resigning at Chapman and joining Gale; (7) Harvey had a
  right to rely on Simmonâ€™s representation; and (8) Harvey suffered injury as a
  result of the false representation, namely his employment with Gale was
  terminated.Â   
Because
  the verdict is supported by at least one unappealed claim, the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule
  applies, and thus, we affirm the jury verdict.Â   
II.  Jury Charge 
Appellants
  also claim the trial court
  failed to adequately charge the jury on the requirements necessary to modify a
  written contract and were thereby prejudiced by the deficiencies in the charge.Â 
  We disagree.
â€œWhen reviewing a jury charge for alleged error, an appellate
  court must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues
  presented at trial.Â  If the charge is reasonably free from error, isolated
  portions which might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.â€Â  Welch
    v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 311, 536 S.E.2d 408, 425 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing Keaton
      ex. rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 334 S.C. 488, 497-98, 514 S.E.2d
  570, 575 (1999)).  
We find the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule also applies to Appellantsâ€™ claim of
  an erroneous jury charge.Â  In Bryant v. Waste Mgmt., Inc., this Court
  applied the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule in a similar circumstance.Â  342 S.C. 159, 536
  S.E.2d 380 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In that case, Bryant asserted six theories of
  negligence, and the jury returned a general verdict in his favor. Â Id. at 167-68, 536 S.E.2d at 384-85. Â On appeal, Waste Management claimed, â€œ[T]he
  trial court erred in instructing the jury that a violation of federal
  Occupational Safety Health Administrations . . . regulations constitutes
  negligence per se.â€Â  Id. at 166, 536 S.E.2d at 384.Â  This Court agreed
  but affirmed the verdict, relying on the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule, noting:  

	Waste Management, however, has not shown it was prejudiced by [the
  erroneous jury instruction] because there existed other bases upon which the
  jury could find it liable. . . . Because the jury rendered a general verdict
  and could have relied upon any of these [other] allegations of negligence to
  find Waste Management liable and because there is ample evidence supporting at
  least one of these [other] allegations . . . we cannot say Waste Management was
  prejudiced by the jury charge in issue. 

Id. at
  167-68, 536 S.E.2d at 384-85.  
As
  previously discussed, this case was submitted to the jury on three claims.Â 
  Because we find the issue of modification relates only to the intentional
  interference with contract claim and at least one of the two unappealed claims
  supported the verdict, whether the trial judge erred in his instruction on
  modification is inconsequential.Â  See Piedmont Aviation, Inc. v.
    Quinn, 294 S.C. 502, 505, 366 S.E.2d 31, 32-33 (Ct. App. 1988) (holding
  when a case is submitted to a jury on two causes of action and the jury returns
  a general verdict, an error by the trial court in its instructions on one
  theory of recovery is of no consequence when the verdict is supported by the
  second theory).
III.  Damages 
Last,
  Appellants argue the trial court erred in not granting Chapmanâ€™s JNOV motion on
  the issue of punitive damages because the trial court could not have reasonably
  found the requisite wantonness and recklessness required for an award of
  punitive damages.Â  Appellants claim because Simmons acted only through his
  attorney and at the advice of counsel, he cannot be found to have acted
  wantonly or recklessly.Â  We disagree.  
â€œThe
  issue of punitive damages must be submitted to the jury if more than one
  reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence as to whether the
  defendantâ€™s behavior was reckless, willful, or wanton.â€Â  Welch, 342 S.C.
  at 301, 536 S.E.2d at 419 (citation omitted).Â  â€œOn appeal from a denial of a
  motion for directed verdict or JNOV [relative to punitive damages], the
  appellate court may only reverse if there is no evidence to support the circuit
  courtâ€™s ruling.â€Â  Mishoe v. QHG of Lake City, Inc., 366 S.C. 195,
  200-01, 621 S.E.2d 363, 366 (Ct. App. 2005) (citation omitted).Â   
As an
  affirmative defense, Appellants raise the argument that they should not be held
  accountable because they acted only through their attorney and relied on the
  advice of counsel.Â  South Carolina has recognized that acting in good faith
  under the advice of counsel is a defense to punitive damages.Â  See Harwell v. Mut. Benefit Health & Accident Assâ€™n, 207
  S.C. 150, 169, 35 S.E.2d 160, 168 (1945) (Baker, C.J., dissenting); see also Kuznik v. Bees Ferry Assocs., 342 S.C. 579, 611, 538 S.E.2d 15, 32
  (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Appellants rely on Kuznik for the notion that acting
  under the advice of counsel is an absolute defense to punitive damages.Â  In Kuznik,
  members of a partnership exercised a contractual right they knew would have
  â€œdevastating legal consequencesâ€ for one of their partners.Â  Id. at 612,
  538 S.E.2d at 32.Â  The master-in-equity found the partners relied on the advice
  of counsel and therefore could not be liable for punitive damages.Â  Id.Â  On appeal, this Court affirmed the masterâ€™s decision, stating advice of counsel
  is a factor that should be considered when determining whether a defendant has
  acted willfully, wantonly, or recklessly.Â  Id.Â  However, this Court
  emphasized advice of counsel is â€œmerely one factor to be consideredâ€ when
  addressing punitive damages.Â  Id.Â   
Other
  than the letter, which Simmons testified he asked his attorney to send,
  Appellants did not present evidence that they received any legal â€œadviceâ€ or
  relied upon that advice.Â  Further, we find Harvey presented evidence of bad
  faith on behalf of Chapman.Â  Because there is some evidence to support the
  trial courtâ€™s decision to submit the issue of punitive damages to the jury, we
  affirm the award of punitive damages.Â Â   
CONCLUSION
We
  find Appellants failed to appeal all three claims submitted to the jury, which
  returned a general verdict, and therefore, the â€œtwo issueâ€ rule applies.Â 
  Because the verdict is supported by at least one of the two unappealed claims,
  we affirm the jury verdict and find whether the judge erred in his jury instruction on modification is
  of no consequence.Â  Further, we hold some evidence was presented to submit the
  issue of punitive damages to the jury.Â  Based on the foregoing, the jury
  verdict and damage award isÂ   
AFFIRMED.[1]Â  
STILWELL,
  SHORT and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. McCall
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Robert Duncan
      McCall, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-453
Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  10, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				J. FalknerÂ  Wilkes, of Greenville; for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney John
  W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General David A. Spencer, of Columbia; Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville;
  for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Robert Duncan McCall appeals his convictions for the offenses of criminal
  sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree and committing a lewd act upon
  a minor.Â  At issue in this appeal is whether the trial judge erred in denying
  McCallâ€™s motion for an independent psychological examination of the victim.Â  We
  affirm.[1]
FACTS
A
  grand jury in Greenville County indicted McCall for the offenses of criminal
  sexual conduct with a minor in the first degree and committing a lewd act on a
  minor.Â  The victim was McCallâ€™s niece by marriage.  
On
  October 24, 2003, the trial court, Judge Edward W. Miller presiding, held a
  hearing on McCallâ€™s motion to have the victim undergo an independent
  psychological or psychiatric evaluation.Â  In support of the motion, counsel for
  McCall noted the following:Â  (1) the victim was a special needs student; (2)
  the victim went through two rounds of group therapy at a sexual trauma center and
  was told she could not do a third round; (3) the victimâ€™s mother once stated
  the victim wanted to recant her accusations against McCall; (4) the defense was
  willing to pay for the evaluation and had identified three psychiatrists who
  could perform it; (5) the charges against McCall were based in part on
  incidents allegedly occurring as long as six years before the victim came
  forward; (7) the indictments were based primarily on statements by the victim
  and her mother; and (8) there were possible â€œfantasy issuesâ€ between the victim
  and McCall.Â  Counsel further submitted an affidavit with hearsay evidence that
  the victim engaged in masturbation and once allowed a cousin to shave off her
  pubic hair.
In
  response, the solicitor objected to the motion, noting the victimâ€™s handicaps
  were orthopedic rather than emotional and she was a mainstream student who had
  achieved good grades and did not have behavior
  problems.Â  The solicitor further asserted the therapy the victim received was
  necessitated by the alleged sexual abuse on which the indictments were based and
  problems associated with her physical disabilities rather than on any emotional
  or psychological abnormalities.Â  Similarly, the solicitor averred the excessive
  masturbation could be â€œassociated with a history of sexual abuse.â€Â 
  Finally, the solicitor dismissed the shaving incident as a â€œchildhood anticâ€
  that was not indicative of any sexually deviant behavior on the victimâ€™s part.
By
  written order dated October 24, 2003, Judge Miller denied McCallâ€™s motion for
  an independent evaluation of the victim.Â  In the same order, however, he
  ordered the State â€œto turn over any and all records of psychological evaluation
  of the Victim as soon as possibleâ€ and granted McCall â€œleave to revisit this
  issue if review of these documents shows a compelling need for psychological
  evaluation of the Victim.â€  
Following a trial
  by jury before Judge C. Victor Pyle on January 12-15, 2004, McCall was
  convicted of both offenses and received concurrent sentences of twenty years on
  the charge of first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor and fifteen
  years on the charge of lewd act on a minor. This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Relying on In
  re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 602 S.E.2d 729 (2004), both at trial and on
  appeal, McCall asserts his motion to have the victim undergo an independent
  evaluation should have been granted.Â  In addition to the arguments he raised
  during the pre-trial hearing, he also argues on appeal that, during the trial,
  the victimâ€™s allegations changed dramatically from what she related during the
  investigation.Â  Finally, McCall notes that, contrary to Judge Millerâ€™s
  instructions, no treatment records for the victim had been made available to
  him.Â  We hold McCall failed to preserve his arguments for appellate review.
A trial judge has
  the discretion â€œto order a psychological examination in cases in which the
  child is the complaining victimâ€ upon a showing of â€œcompelling need.â€Â  In re
    Michael H., 360 S.C. at 551-52, 602 S.E.2d at 735.Â  The trial judge,
  however, must have the opportunity to determine whether such an examination is
  warranted in a particular case.Â  Id. at 546, 602 S.E.2d at 732.Â   
Like McCall, the
  defendant in Michael H. unsuccessfully moved before the final hearing took
  place to have the complaining witness submit to a psychological evaluation.Â  Id. at 544, 602 S.E.2d at 731.Â  Unlike McCall, however, the defendant in Michael
    H. moved again to have the complainant submit to a psychological evaluation
  after a clinical psychologist treating the complainant testified at trial and
  defense counsel discovered he had not received notes concerning reports by the
  complainant that â€œhe [the complainant] had been hearing voices in his head for
  some time.â€Â  Id. at 544-45, 602 S.E.2d at 731.
In contrast, during
  the jury trial in the present case, defense counsel made only a passing
  reference to his prior motion to have the victim evaluated, stating at the
  beginning of the hearing, â€œAnd just for the record I would like to note that I
  still objected to that ruling just to protect myself.â€Â  At no time did defense
  counsel expressly argue that the inconsistencies between the victimâ€™s trial
  testimony and her statements during the investigation warranted an order for
  her to submit to a psychological evaluation, and we see no way to construe
  counselâ€™s statements to encompass such an assertion. Â Similarly, the record
  does not show any attempt by the defense to compel the State to release the
  victimâ€™s treatment records.Â  See State v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221,
  258, 609 S.E.2d 572, 591 (Ct. App. 2005), cert. granted (Oct. 19, 2006) (â€œA general objection
  which does not specify the particular ground on which the objection is based is
  insufficient to preserve the issue for review.â€).Â  Because the
  trial judge never had the opportunity to consider, much less rule on, whether
  the information elicited during the trial would constitute a compelling reason
  to order a psychological evaluation of the victim or whether McCall was
  unjustifiably deprived of access to the victimâ€™s treatment records, we cannot
  address these issues on appeal.Â   
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and
  THOMAS, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.  

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Erika W. v. Vanessa W.
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Erika W. and
      Rodney W., Appellants,
				v.
				Vanessa Lee
      W., Dusty Ray S., and Emily Faith S., a minor under the age of fourteen (14)
      years, Respondents. 
			
		
	


Appeal From Cherokee County
Gerald C. Smoak, Jr., Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-459
Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  11, 2007Â Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Usha Jeffries Bridges and William G.
  Rhoden, both of Gaffney, for Appellants.
				Dusty
  Ray S., of Mooresboro; Vanessa Lee W., of Gaffney, for Respondents.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM: Â Â Erika W. and Rodney W. (Grandparents) brought this
  action seeking to terminate the parental rights of Vanessa Lee W. (Mother) and
  Dusty Ray S. (Father).Â  Grandparents sought to adopt their granddaughter after
  the termination.Â  The family court found Mother consented to their termination
  and, in its amended order, terminated her parental rights.Â  However, the court
  denied the request to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights based on either a
  failure to visit or a failure to support the child.[1] Â 
FACTS
The child was born
  in August 2000, and Mother and Father were living together at the time.Â  In
  2003, Grandparents took custody of the child.Â  Rodney W. (Grandfather)
  testified he visited the childâ€™s home in November 2003 and the child opened the
  door.Â  He was unable to wake the parents, so he took custody of the child.Â  The
  parents finally called later that afternoon.Â  Several days later, Grandfather
  called the home and Mother hung up on him.Â  He again went to the home only to
  find it had been ransacked.Â  In the process of helping clean the house,
  Grandfather found numerous items of drug paraphernalia.Â   
A family court
  order filed December 3, 2004, granted custody to Grandparents and required
  Mother and Father to pay child support.Â  Specifically, Father was ordered to
  pay $50 per week in child support through the court.Â  The order allowed
  supervised visitation for the parents.Â  Fatherâ€™s visitation was supervised by
  his parents.Â   
In April 2005,
  Father went to jail for violating probation for his unauthorized use of a motor
  vehicle.Â  At the same time, he was on probation in North Carolina for felony
  fleeing, alluding arrest in a motor vehicle, possession of a schedule two
  narcotic, driving while license is revoked, speeding, and public passing.Â  Upon
  his release in South Carolina in October 2005, he had to spend a month in jail
  in North Carolina.Â  While in jail, he sent at least one letter to his daughter,
  but he did not pay any child support.Â  He called to speak to his daughter
  either while in jail or once he got out.
After he was
  released, Father failed to make most of his required child support payments;
  however, he had difficulty obtaining a job upon his release.Â  In addition, he
  had little to no visitation with his daughter after his release.Â  The parties
  dispute the reason for the lack of visitation.Â   
In January 2006,
  Grandparents brought this action to terminate the parental rights of Mother and
  Father.Â  The action was brought against Father on the grounds that he willfully
  failed to support and willfully failed to visit his daughter for a period of at
  least six months.Â  Grandparents sought to adopt the child.Â  Mother signed a
  relinquishment of rights and consented to the adoption prior to trial.Â  Father, pro se, contested the TPR action and the adoption.
The family court
  issued an order finding Fatherâ€™s failure to support and failure to visit was
  not willful.Â  The court found he was incarcerated and had difficulty obtaining
  work.Â  The family court noted he paid some child support and had regular
  visitation prior to going to jail.Â  The court denied the termination of
  Motherâ€™s parental rights.Â  The court did not address whether termination would
  be in the best interest of the child.
Grandparents filed
  a motion to reconsider, arguing they provided sufficient proof of Fatherâ€™s
  failure to support and visit.Â  They maintained Mother voluntarily relinquished
  her rights and the court should have terminated her rights.Â  The court agreed
  Motherâ€™s rights should have been terminated.Â  However, the court found
  Grandparents failed to carry their burden of proof to show Fatherâ€™s failure to
  support and visit was willful.Â  The court, therefore, denied the termination of
  Fatherâ€™s parental rights.Â  Again, the court did not address the best interest
  of the child.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section
  20-7-1578 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) mandates that the TPR
  statutes â€œmust be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial
  procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and control of their
  parents by terminating the parent-child relationship.â€Â  See also Joiner
    v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 536 S.E.2d 372 (2000) (overruling prior cases
  calling for strict construction of the TPR statutes).Â  â€œThe interests of the
  child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€Â 
  S.C. Code Ann.Â  Â§ 20-7-1578.Â  Grounds for termination of parental rights must
  be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of
    Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 608-09, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003)
  (citing Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 102 S. Ct. 1388, 71 L. Ed. 2d
  599 (1982)).
In
  appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its
  own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v.
    Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992); Owens v.
      Owens, 320 S.C. 543, 546, 466 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  However,
  this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s
  findings.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616,
  617 (1981).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and
  heard witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and
  assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276
  S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981); Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511,
  516, 586 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App.Â  2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Grandparents
  contend the family court erred in finding Fatherâ€™s failure to visit and failure
  to support his child for six months was not willful due at least in part to his
  incarceration.Â  They maintain the court used the wrong standard in considering
  Fatherâ€™s incarceration as a mitigating factor.Â   
The
  family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one
  or more of eleven statutory grounds and a finding that termination is in the
  best interest of the child.Â  The relevant grounds in this case are:

	(3)Â  The child has lived outside the home of either
  parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully
  failed to visit the child.Â  The court may attach little or no weight to
  incidental visitations, but it must be shown that the parent was not prevented
  from visiting by the party having custody or by court order.Â  The distance of
  the childâ€™s placement from the parentâ€™s home must be taken into consideration
  when determining the ability to visit;
	(4)Â  The child has lived outside the home of either
  parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully
  failed to support the child.Â  Failure to support means that the parent has
  failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s care.Â  A material
  contribution consists of either financial contribution according to the
  parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other
  necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means.Â  The
  court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the
  parent has willfully failed to support the child, including requests for support
  by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support â€¦.


S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005).Â   

Willful
  conduct is conduct that â€œevinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties â€¦
  because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to
  receive support and consortium from the parent.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs.
    v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 53, 413 S.E.2d 835, 838 (1992).Â  Whether a parent
  has willfully failed to visit or support his or her child is a â€œquestion of
  intent to be determined from the facts and circumstances of each individual
  case.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 610, 582
  S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003); Stinecipher v. Ballington, 366 S.C. 92, 98, 620
  S.E.2d 93, 96 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The family court has wide discretion to make
  this determination, but the element of willfulness must be established by clear
  and convincing evidence.Â  Broome, 307 S.C. at 52, 413 S.E.2d at 838.Â 
  â€œThe court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or
  not the parent has willfully failed to support the child, including â€¦ the
  ability of the parent to provide support.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann.Â  Â§ 20-7-1572.Â  
 

Incarceration
  alone is insufficient to justify TPR.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs.
    v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 332, 337, 543 S.E.2d 580, 583 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In Wilson, the father was incarcerated after the birth of his three children.Â  We
  reversed the family courtâ€™s grant of TPR, holding that â€œ[t]erminating the
  parental rights of an incarcerated parent requires consideration of all of the
  surrounding facts and circumstances in the determination of wilfullness.â€Â  Id. at 340, 543 S.E.2d at 584.Â  We noted the record was replete with evidence of not
  only the fatherâ€™s repeated requests to the Department to visit his children,
  but the Departmentâ€™s active role in thwarting the fatherâ€™s attempts to visit
  his children.Â  Id. at 338, 543 S.E.2d at 583.Â   

In
  the instant case, everyone acknowledges Father regularly maintained his
  visitation prior to his incarceration, seeing his daughter at least once a
  month until his incarceration.Â  Upon incarceration, his efforts to maintain
  contact greatly diminished.Â  He only sent a couple letters and made a couple
  phone calls.Â  He offered no explanation for the drop off in contact.Â  Father
  asserted at the hearing that, after he was released from incarceration, he and
  his grandparents attempted to obtain visitation from Grandparents. Father
  claimed he was told that Grandparents had to discuss the possibility of
  visitation with their attorneys.Â  As a result, there was no visitation by
  Father after he was released.Â  The evidence is not nearly as strong as that
  provided in the Wilson case.Â  However, the family court concluded
  Grandparents had not met their burden to prove by clear and convincing evidence
  that the failure to visit was willful.Â  Accordingly, the courtâ€™s determination
  should be given deference.Â   

As
  to the failure to support, there is significantly less evidence in Fatherâ€™s
  favor.Â  He made almost no payments to Grandparents prior to the December 3
  order.Â  After the order, he made no payments through the court as required
  until December 2005.Â  In total, he only made $110 in payments, and, at the time
  of the hearing, was in arrears $3,932.50.Â  Even if the period of his incarceration
  and the time he was unemployed were considered excused, he never made payments
  through the court as he was supposed to prior to his incarceration.Â  In
  addition, he only made two total payments between his release in November 2005
  and the hearing in May 2006.

Father
  testified he made some payments to Grandparents after they first obtained
  custody.Â  He testified that he had a hard time finding employment after he was
  released from incarceration.Â  Additionally, he admitted he did not pay â€œlike I
  was supposed to.â€Â  Finally, he testified that he has withheld support due to
  his inability to obtain visitation with his child since his incarceration.

In
  looking at the family court history of payments, he has only made two payments
  through the court between December 2004 and May 2006.Â  Even if the
  incarceration and the subsequent unemployment were omitted, he still went
  significant periods of time without making payments of support as ordered by
  the court.Â  The only mitigating factor is the failure of the Grandparents to
  show how much Father could have paid.Â  Father admitted he was employed prior to
  his incarceration and did not make payments as he should.Â  In addition, he
  admitted that, at the time of the hearing, he was making about $600 per month
  and failed to provide support. Accordingly, this court finds by clear and
  convincing evidence that Father failed to support his child.Â  Â 

When
  adjudicating a TPR case, the best interests of the child are paramount.Â  S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 298, 547 S.E.2d 506, 511 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Once a statutory ground has been proven, section 20-7-1572 of the South
  Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) requires that the best interest of the child must be
  served by termination of parental rights.Â  Our supreme court has held that the
  termination of parental rights statute should be liberally construed consistent
  with the purpose to facilitate prompt adoption and the best interest of the
  child.Â  Joiner v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 536 S.E.2d 372 (2000).

Here,
  we conclude that the issue of the best interest of the child should be remanded
  to the family court for a full evidentiary hearing on this issue.Â   
CONCLUSION
For
  the foregoing reasons, we find Grandparents met their burden to show Father
  willfully failed to support his child.Â  We find the issue of the best interest
  of the child should be remanded to the family court for a full evidentiary
  hearing on this issue.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the family court is

REVERSEDÂ  AND
  REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., AND
  ANDERSON, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Dawkins v. Dawkins
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Alice Dawkins, Respondent,
				v.
				Steve Dawkins, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Cherokee County
Georgia V. Anderson, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-460
Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October 11, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; REMANDED


	
		
			
				Richard H. Rhodes, of Spartanburg, for
  Appellant.
				William G. Rhoden and Usha J. Bridges,
  of Gaffney, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  In this domestic action,
  Steve Dawkins (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s (1) apportionment of marital
  property, (2) failure to provide Husband a special equity in the workersâ€™ compensation
  award and the marital home, (3) failure to award Dawkins Automotive to Husband in
  the division of marital assets, and (4) award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in
  part, reverse in part, and remand.[1]
FACTS
The
  parties in this divorce action were married in June 1980, and separated on
  August 14, 2002.Â  During their twenty-two year marriage, Husband and Alice
  Dawkins (Wife) acquired numerous rental properties and a business, Dawkins
  Automotive.Â  Husband suffered an on-the-job injury in 1995 while employed with
  John Montgomery Development and collected a $78,000.00 workersâ€™ compensation award.Â 
  He invested a substantial amount of those benefits in Dawkins Automotive.
Wife
  filed this divorce action on September 10, 2002.Â  In her complaint, Wife prayed
  for use of the marital home and the right to operate the family business
  (Dawkins Automotive).Â  An emergency hearing addressing these concernments was
  scheduled for October 10, 2002.Â  Husband filed an affidavit seeking to operate
  the business and to gain access to the business records in Wifeâ€™s possession.
A
  temporary order was entered on November 1, 2002, giving Wife control of the business
  and directing her to account each week for business income and expenses.Â  The
  order provided:Â  (1) Husband would make repairs on vehicles for the business,
  and return them to Wife, who would sell them for Dawkins Automotive; (2) Wife would
  furnish the tools and parts for Husbandâ€™s repair of the vehicles; (3) Husband
  and Wife would agree upon a Certified Public Accountant (CPA) who would conduct
  an audit, determine the money received, the automobiles sold, the expenses paid,
  and the money disbursed; (4) Wonketia Dawkins (the partiesâ€™ daughter) would
  manage and collect rent from the partiesâ€™ mutually owned rental properties and make
  a monthly accounting; (5) Husband and Wife would make an accounting of rent collected
  by either party prior to the order date; and (6) either party could petition
  for relief from the terms of the order.
On
  November 14, 2002, Husband filed an Answer and Counterclaim to Wifeâ€™s initial
  Complaint requesting control over Dawkins Automotive and the business records
  in Wifeâ€™s possession.Â  At a follow-up hearing held December 3, 2002, Husband
  contended Wife failed to provide business records and was uncooperative with
  the repair and sale of vehicles for Dawkins Automotive.Â   
An
  order dated January 8, 2003, was issued:Â  (1) compelling the parties to present
  receipts and expenses related to the rental properties, received since the date
  of separation; (2) prohibiting the parties from accepting any rent or making
  any payments on behalf of the rental properties; (3) requiring Wonketia Dawkins
  to provide rental reports for November and December of 2002, as well as every
  month thereafter, showing all rent received and all expenses paid; (4)
  instructing the parties to produce a complete accounting of income and expenses
  related to the sale of used cars, both personally and for Dawkins Automotive; (5)
  commanding Husband to provide a written document on each car to be repaired to
  Wife, listing the needed parts, where they can be purchased, and their approximate
  cost; (6) dictating that Wife review the car repair documents with Husband and
  either provide him with the parts or the funds to obtain the parts; (7)
  directing the parties to give an inventory of all equipment in their respective
  possessions; and (8) stating when either party receives the income tax refund
  for 2001, provide it immediately to their attorney.
In
  January of 2004, Husband filed a motion requesting the information previously
  ordered by the court on January 8, 2003, and a hearing was held on January 29,
  2004.Â  On February 10, 2004, a temporary order was issued expressing the family
  courtâ€™s dissatisfaction with the extent of compliance with the prior order.Â  It
  directed the parties to comply by providing:Â   

	Each
  asset must be reviewed separately as to income and expenses to properly
  account.Â  Beginning August 18, 2002, both parties must therefore provide the
  Court and the other party an accounting of each asset (by the name of the
  asset) on which either has received income and all incurred expenses, supported
  by receipts and cancelled checks.Â  This includes automobiles and real estate.Â 
  Either party can then see what the other contends about a particular asset and
  the Court can determine whether there has been a net gain or a net loss on any
  particular asset.
	Wonketia
  Dawkins must provide by location of each rental property, an accounting of all
  rent received and all expenses paid beginning November 1, 2002.Â  Again this
  will allow the parties and the Court to view each asset separately and make a
  determination of net gain or net loss.
	Both
  Plaintiff and Defendant must provide the other and this Court a list of all
  vehicles in his/her possession on August 18, 2002 as well as any vehicles
  acquired or sold subsequent to that date to include name of vehicles, to whom
  sold, purchase price, sales price, expenses to repair and monthly payments, if
  any.
	All of
  the aforesaid must be provided by the parties to their respective attorneys
  within 10 days.Â  In addition Wonketia Dawkins is hereby named as a party
  defendant and she is to be served with a copy of this Order and required to
  comply with the accounting within 10 days after service.

After
  Husband sought a Rule to Show Cause alleging Wife was not producing rental
  information or other court ordered documents, Wife presented a voluminous box
  of documents at a hearing on May 4, 2004.Â  From the hearing, a temporary order
  was entered on June 14, 2004, continuing the hearing and stating that it
  appeared Wife and Wonketia Dawkins complied with the prior order, and the
  matter may be rescheduled if necessary.
On
  October 5, 2005, the court held a status conference where it required Wife to
  present within thirty days:Â  (1) index cards of paid out accounts for car sales;
  (2) monthly reports filed with the South Carolina Tax Commission beginning with
  September 2002; (3) a list of automobiles sold and their respective buyers for
  the years of 2004 and 2005; (4) income and expense information on the rental
  properties for 2004 and 2005; and (5) a composition book of Husbandâ€™s recorded
  car sales, if available.Â  In addition, the court instructed Husband to provide an
  accounting of the following within thirty days:Â  (1) maintenance proceeds; (2) rents
  received from two of the rental properties; and (3) all car sales.
As a
  result of Wifeâ€™s non-production of the documents outlined in the status conference,
  Husband filed a petition requesting a Rule to Show Cause and the hearing was
  held on December 15, 2005.Â  At the hearing, Wife presented a plethora of
  documents purported to contain the information requested.Â  Under the assumption
  the CPA would be able to find the necessary data to construct his report, the
  hearing was continued by an order dated December 28, 2005.
On
  December 19, 2005, Husband filed a Rule to Show Cause alleging Wife had not
  complied with the prior orders of the court.Â  This petition was scheduled to be
  heard at the final hearing on January 11, 2006.Â  A divorce decree was entered
  on March 19, 2006, providing in relevant parts:

	R.   Distribution List Follows.
	The
  marital properties and debts shall be divided pursuant to the list attached
  hereto.Â  While the Plaintiff is to receive more than the Defendant, the
  Plaintiff is taking responsibility for all the marital debt which is secured by
  the properties that she is receiving.Â  The Court has considered the relative
  fault in the breakup of the marriage as well as the Plaintiffâ€™s earnest and
  commendable efforts in maintaining the parties [sic] properties and good credit
  during the pendency of this action.Â  Assets received by the Defendant are debt
  free.Â  Further, the Plaintiff needs the assets that she will be receiving to
  support herself in the future.Â  Both parties should cooperate in the signing of
  any documents necessary to comply with the terms of this Orderâ€¦.
	10.Â  The
  Court finds that in regard to attorney [sic] fees both parties have contributed
  to the prolonged contentiousness of this case.Â  However, the most significant
  act, or failure to act was that of the Plaintiff in not timely producing the
  September 2002 accounts receivable list with the supporting documentation.Â  The
  Court finds that had this been done in a timely manner, this case may have very
  well have been less expensive and been ready for trial earlier.Â  The Court
  considers this factor in the request for attorneyâ€™s fees rather than as a
  separate contempt issue.Â  The Plaintiff shall contribute $7,500.00 toward the
  Defendantâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees within six months of the date of this Order paying
  this directly to Mr. Thompson.Â  In consideration of his fault in the break up
  of the marriage, [t]he Defendant shall contribute $3,000.00 toward the
  Plaintiffâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees within six months of the date of this Order paying
  this amount directly to Mrs. Bridges.Â  The remaining legal expenses shall be paid
  the party incurring them.

Husband
  filed a Motion for Reconsideration pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  On May 18,
  2006, an amended divorce decree was entered which modified the original order,
  in relevant part:Â   

	Page 11,
  R.Â  Distribution List Follows.Â  The following paragraph should be substituted.
	The
  marital properties and debts shall be divided pursuant to the amended and
  modified asset distribution list attached hereto, wherein the Plaintiff will be
  receiving 60% of the marital assets, and the Defendant 40%.Â  The Court has
  considered the relative fault in the breakup of the marriage, as well as
  Plaintiffâ€™s earnest and commendable efforts in maintaining the parties [sic] assets
  and good credit during the pendency of this action.Â  Consideration has also
  been given to the fact that Defendantâ€™s real estate assets are all debt free,
  while Plaintiff takes with hers a debt obligation of $140,937.Â  The only real
  estate taken by Plaintiff lien free is the property occupied by the partiesâ€™
  daughter, and for which neither party required the payment of rent prior to
  their separation.
	Additionally,
  Plaintiff will have the right to operate the business known as Dawkins Auto
  free of any claims by the Defendant.Â  To accomplish a final distribution, the
  Plaintiff owes the Defendant $21,422.00, which is to be paid in full by July 1,
  2007.
	The
  remaining requests by the Defendant to Alter and/or Amend are hereby denied,
  and the March 19, 2006 order remains in full force and effect, except as herein
  as modified.

ISSUES

	
		
			1. 
			Did the family court err in
  apportioning the marital property in a sixty/forty division, granting Wife sixty
  percent of the marital estate?
 
		
		
			2. 
			Did the family court err in denying
  Husband a special equity in the workersâ€™ compensation award and the marital
  home?
 
		
		
			3.  
			Did the family court err by
  allocating Dawkins Automotive to Wife when dividing the marital assets?
 
		
		
			4.
			Did the family court err by
  instructing Husband to pay Wife $3,000 toward her attorneyâ€™s fee while only
  awarding Husband $7,500 from Wife for his attorneyâ€™s fee?
		
	

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In
  appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its
  own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Nasser-Moghaddassi v.
    Moghaddassi, 364 S.C. 182, 189, 612 S.E.2d 707, 711 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Emery v. Smith, 361 S.C. 207, 213, 603 S.E.2d 598, 601 (Ct. App.
  2004)).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require this court to
  disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Lacke v. Lacke, 362 S.C. 302,
  307, 608 S.E.2d 147, 149 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Bowers v. Bowers, 349
  S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d 610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002)); Badeaux v. Davis, 337

DISCUSSION
1.  Equitable Division of
  Marital Property
Husband
  asserts the family court erred when apportioning the marital estate in a sixty/forty
  split in favor of Wife.Â  We agree.Â  The appropriate division of property is a fifty/fifty
  partition to each spouse.
The
  apportionment of marital property is within the discretion of the family court
  judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  See Morris
    v. Morris, 295 S.C. 37, 39, 367 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1988).Â  Section 20-7-472 of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) provides fifteen factors the family court
  must consider, giving each weight as it determines.Â  These factors are:Â  (1) the
  duration of the marriage, (2) any marital misconduct or fault and its effect on
  the break-up of the marriage, (3) the value of marital property and the
  contribution of each spouse in the acquisition, preservation, depreciation, or
  appreciation, including the contribution of a homemaker, (4) the income and
  earning potential of each spouse and opportunity for future acquisition of
  assets, (5) the health, both physical and emotional, of each spouse, (6) the need
  of either spouse for additional training or education, (7) the nonmarital
  property of each spouse, (8) the existence or nonexistence of vested retirement
  benefits for each spouse, (9) whether alimony has been awarded, (10) the desirability
  of awarding the family home, (11) the tax consequence to each spouse as a
  result of the apportionment, (12) the existence and extent of any support
  obligations of either party, (13) any liens and encumbrances on marital and
  separate property and other existing debts, (14) any child custody arrangements
  and obligations, and (15) any other relevant factors as the trial court shall
  expressly enumerate in its order.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2006).
On
  review, this Court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment, and if
  the end result is equitable, the fact that this court might have weighed
  specific factors differently than the family court is irrelevant.Â  Johnson
    v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300-01, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988); see Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 502, 478 S.E.2d 854, 859 (Ct. App. 1996) (The
  reviewing court will affirm the family court judgeâ€™s apportionment of marital
  property if it can be determined that the judge addressed the relevant factors
  under section 20-7-472 with sufficiency for the reviewing court to conclude the
  judge was cognizant of the statutory factors.).
The
  court may acknowledge the grounds for divorce when apportioning the marital estate.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(2) (Supp. 2006).Â  However, a severe penalty for fault
  is prohibited:Â  â€œAlthough fault does not justify a severe penalty in making a
  division of marital property, it is a factor the court may consider in
  determining the equities between spouses.â€ Rampey v. Rampey, 286 S.C.
  153, 156, 332 S.E.2d 213, 214 (Ct. App. 1985); Simmons v. Simmons, 275
  S.C. 41, 44-45, 267 S.E.2d 427, 429 (1980).
While
  there is no bright line rule, this Court suggests an equal fifty/fifty split of
  marital assets as an appropriate beginning point for dividing the estate of a
  long-term marriage.Â  Craig v. Craig, 358 S.C. 548, 557, 595
  S.E.2d 837, 842 (Ct. App. 2004) (affirming fifty-fifty apportionment of the
  marital estate in a twenty-seven-year marriage), affâ€™d by 365 S.C. 285,
  617 S.E.2d 359 (2005); Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 503, 478 S.E.2d 854,
  859 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding a fifty-fifty apportionment appropriate where the
  marriage lasted over thirty years); Harlan v. Harlan, 300 S.C. 537, 545,
  389 S.E.2d 165, 170 (Ct. App. 1990) (upholding a fifty-fifty division of the
  marital assets for an eighteen-year marriage); Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 199, 363 S.E.2d 404, 407 (Ct. App. 1987) (preserving a
  fifty-fifty split in a marriage of eighteen years); Leatherwood v.
    Leatherwood, 293 S.C. 148, 150, 359 S.E.2d 89, 90 (Ct. App. 1987)
  (approving a fifty-fifty apportionment of marital property after a twenty-two
  year marriage).
In Doe
  v. Doe, 370 S.C. 206, 215, 634 S.E.2d 51, 56 (Ct. App. 2006), the
  family court partitioned the marital estate in a seventy/thirty proportion in
  favor of the husband considering the wifeâ€™s marital misconduct.Â  Id. at 214, 634 S.E.2d at 55.Â  We found this division to be inequitable and
  re-assigned the estate in a sixty/forty distribution.Â  Id. at 215, 634
  S.E.2d at 56.Â  This Court elucidated:

	In light
  of the marriageâ€™s longevity, our prohibition against imposing a severe penalty
  for fault, and the family courtâ€™s erroneous consideration of Dr. Woodsideâ€™s
  testimony, we find the family court abused its discretion when it awarded
  Husband seventy percent of the marital estate.Â  We believe the more equitable

Id. at 216; 634 S.E.2d at 57.Â  Doe is
  distinguished from the present case because the wifeâ€™s marital misconduct

  child when the biological father was actually the wifeâ€™s paramour, a longtime
  family friend.Â  Id.
Widman
  v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 557 S.E.2d
  693 (Ct. App. 2001), upheld an equal division of the marital estate under
  circumstances similar to the instant case.Â  In Widman, the court granted
  the wife a divorce on the ground of adultery, ending a sixteen year marriage.Â  Id. at 108, 557 S.E.2d at 699.Â  
 

	â€œIn its
  decree, the trial court found [the wife] to be in willful violation of the
  courtâ€™s order for (1) failing to file proper financial declarations as previously
  ordered, (2) disclosing information to [the husbandâ€™s] parents and adult

Id.Â  The court applied the fifteen factors of South
  Carolina Code section 20-7-472 (Supp. 2006) and found an equitable division of
  property to be a fifty-fifty split between the parties.Â  Id. at 111, 557
  S.E.2d at 700-701.
In
  the case sub judice, the family court stated several facts
  relevant to its equitable division of the marital estate.Â  The court considered
  (1) Husbandâ€™s adulterous affair and its contribution to the break up of the
  marriage, (2) Wifeâ€™s efforts in maintaining the assets and good credit during

  427, 429 (1980), and the trend in case law for an equal apportionment of

2.  Special Equity and
  Characterization of Property as Marital v. Nonmarital
Husband

a.  Special Equity
A
  spouse may claim special equity in marital property, as set forth in South
  Carolina Code section 20-7-471 (Supp. 2006):

	During
  the marriage a spouse shall acquire, based upon the factors set out in Â§
  20-7-472, a vested special equity and ownership right in the marital property

In Webber
  v. Webber, 285 S.C. 425, 427-428, 330 S.E.2d 79, 81 (Ct. App. 1985), this
  Court articulated:

	Under
  the special equity doctrine, â€œWhere a wife has made a material contribution to
  the husbandâ€™s acquisition of property during coverture, she acquires a special

  566, 568 (1978) (quoting 27B C.J.S. Divorce Â§ 293 (1950)).Â  Therefore,
  one spouse acquires a special equity in the property of the other if (1) the
  property was acquired during coverture, (2) the spouse contributed to the
  acquisition of the property, and (3) the spouseâ€™s contribution was material.

To
  acquire a special equity in nonmarital property, the property must appreciate
  during marriage or the non-owner spouse must materially contribute to the
  improvement of the property.Â  Webber, 285 S.C. at 428; 330 S.E.2d at 81

  (1984)).Â  The materiality of the contribution is not expressed in South

  examine â€œ[t]he contribution of each spouse to the acquisition, preservation,
  depreciation, or appreciation in value of the marital property, including the

  consider the quality of the contribution as well as its factual existenceâ€ when

The term

Nevertheless,

  find sufficient evidentiary support in the record to uphold the judgeâ€™s award
  of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, we hold the court did not abuse its
  discretion in this instance.Â  See Robinson v. Tyson, 319 S.C. 360,
  366, 461 S.E.2d 397, 400 (Ct. App. 1995) (no abuse of discretion in ordering
  payment of attorneyâ€™s fees where record contains sufficient evidence to support
  the award); Glasscock, 304 S.C. at 161, 403 S.E.2d at 315.
CONCLUSION

	We
  affirm the ruling of the family court in regard to:
	
		
			1)
			The characterization of the 
			workersâ€™ compensation award as marital, subject to equitable 
			distribution without special equity;
 
		
		
			2)
			The grant of ownership of 
			Dawkins Automotive to Wife incident to the division of the marital 
			estate; and
 
		
		
			3) 
			Attorneyâ€™s fees.
		
	
	We
  reverse the holding of the family court in reference to:
	
		
			1)
			The apportionment of marital 
			property in a sixty/forty split, holding a fifty/fifty division is 
			appropriate; and
 
		
		
			2) 
			 The denial of Husbandâ€™s 
			special equity in the marital home, finding Husband is entitled to a 
			$25,000.00 special equity.
		
	

We
  remand to the family court for re-division of the marital estate in accordance
  with this opinion.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED
  IN PART AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON and THOMAS, J.J.,
  and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
