THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Anthony Douglas, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-496
  Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  16, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Katherine H. Hudgins, of Columbia and Douglas
          Jennings, Jr., of Bennettsville, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
          Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jay E. Hodge,
          Jr., of Cheraw, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In July
  2005, Anthony Douglas was tried and convicted by a Marlboro County jury of distribution of crack cocaine. Douglas timely appeals this conviction contending
  he was deprived of his right to a fair trial due to a police officerâ€™s
  testimony regarding prior drug purchases from Douglas, the solicitorâ€™s closing
  argument remarks on physical evidence not introduced to the jury, and the solicitorâ€™s
  comment upon the pervasiveness of drugs in Marlboro County during his closing
  argument.Â  Douglas argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for
  mistrial on these three grounds.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In
  March 2004, Robert Candrilli (Candrilli), a confidential informant, planned and
  executed a drug purchase under the auspices of the Marlboro County Sheriffâ€™s
  Department. Candrilli met Officers George McLeod (Officer McLeod) and Robert
  Bryant (Officer Bryant) in a secluded area where the officers searched him for
  drugs and money before attaching a â€œwireâ€ or listening device to Candrilli.
  Candrilli proceeded to the Crossroads Grocery where he used a payphone to call Douglasâ€™s cell-phone and request twenty dollars worth of crack cocaine. Douglas arrived ten
  minutes later in a burgundy Buick, gave Candrilli a substance later determined
  to be .15 grams of crack cocaine, collected twenty dollars, and drove away from
  the pay phone booth. 
As
  Douglas drove away from Candrilli, Douglas passed by Officer McLeod who was
  parked on a dirt road a few hundred yards from Crossroads Grocery. Â While
  Officer McLeod could not see the actual exchange of drugs for money, he could
  identify Douglas as the driver of the passing burgundy Buick. 
Immediately
  after the drug transaction, Officer Bryant collected Candrilli from Crossroads
  Grocery and drove him to a secluded location where they met Officer McLeod.
  Candrilli surrendered the crack he had purchased from Douglas and was searched
  again by the officers. Â Douglas was arrested several weeks later and
  indicted for distribution of crack cocaine. Â 
During
  pre-trial motions the trial court ruled that all testimony should be limited to
  the events of March 15, 2004, and witnesses should refrain from discussing Douglasâ€™s prior drug convictions. Upon cross-examination, Officer McLeod testified he was
  able to identify Douglas as the driver of the burgundy Buick because the
  Marlboro County Sheriffâ€™s Department had previously purchased drugs from Douglas. The trial court immediately gave curative instructions that the jury was to
  disregard any testimony regarding any activity of any kind other than the
  events on March 15. The trial court admonished the jury that should they choose
  to accept Officer McLeodâ€™s testimony, it was to be used for identification
  purposes only. Â 
The
  jury heard testimony from Candrilli regarding the date of the drug transaction,
  Douglasâ€™s cell phone number, and the pay phone number at Crossroads Grocery. Â Candrilli
  recited the date and the phone numbers from a slip of paper he possessed on the
  witness stand. Â During cross-examination Candrilli stated he wrote the
  date and time of the drug transaction on the paper but other people had written
  down the numbers for Douglasâ€™s cell phone and the pay phone at Crossroads
  Grocery. Candrilli testified the paper was from his day-timer, however, during
  closing arguments the solicitor matched the paper to his legal pad. The
  solicitor further explained that he wrote down the phone numbers so Candrilli
  could refresh his memory on the witness stand. 
In
  his closing argument the solicitor also commented upon the pervading nature of
  drugs in Marlboro County schools and areas around Marlboro County. He continued to say that if Douglas were found guilty, the jury would â€œbe doing this
  community and this society a wonderful, wonderful favor by taking a drug dealer
  off of the streets.â€ Â After the solicitor finished his closing argument,
  Douglasâ€™s counsel waited until the jury had been charged before making a
  motion for mistrial based on the solicitorâ€™s closing. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to grant or deny a mistrial is
  within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be overturned on
  appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law. State v.
    Stanley, 365 S.C. 24, 33, 615 S.E.2d 455, 460 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œA mistrial should only be granted when â€œabsolutely
  necessary,â€ and a defendant must show both error and resulting prejudice in
  order to be entitled to a mistrial.â€ Id.Â  The granting of a motion for
  mistrial is an extreme measure which should be taken only where an incident is
  so grievous that its prejudicial effect can be removed no other way. Id.Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS

Douglas
  argues the trial court erred in failing to grant his motion for mistrial based
  on the following three events during his trial: (1) Officer McLeodâ€™s testimony
  on cross-examination regarding Douglasâ€™s prior involvement in drug transactions
  other than the March 15, 2004 transaction at issue; (2) the solicitorâ€™s closing
  argument discussion of a slip of paper the confidential informant used to
  recall phone numbers and dates while on the witness stand; and (3) the
  solicitorâ€™s closing argument remarks on the universal problem of drugs and the
  presence of drugs in Marlboro County. We disagree.
I. Officerâ€™s Testimony
During
  cross-examination of Officer McLeod, Douglasâ€™s counsel inquired as to how
  Officer McLeod could look into a vehicle approaching from the direction of the
  Crossroads Grocery and identify the driver. Officer McLeod warned Douglasâ€™s
  counsel he may not like the answer and when Douglasâ€™s counsel pressed him,
  Officer McLeod testified that he could, â€œidentify [the defendant] because that
  was not the first time the Marlboro County Sherriffâ€™s Office had purchased
  drugs from [the] defendant.â€ Douglas argues this testimony should have resulted
  in a mistrial.Â  We disagree.
Evidence of a defendant's crimes, wrongs, or acts is generally not
  admissible. Rule 404(b), SCRE.Â  Our courts view a defendant's previous
  distribution of drugs as a past bad act. State v. King,
  349 S.C. 142, 152, 561 S.E.2d 640, 645 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923),
  and incorporated in Rule 404(b), SCRE, a defendant's prior bad acts may be
  admitted to show: (1) motive; (2) identity; (3) the existence of a common
  scheme or plan; (4) the absence of mistake or accident; or (5) intent.
Pursuant to Rule 403, SCRE, any prejudice resulting from the
  admission of evidence under Rule 404(b), SCRE, must be outweighed by its
  probative value. Â State v. Fletcher, 363 S.C. 221, 242, 609 S.E.2d 572,
  583 (Ct. App. 2005). â€œThe determination of prejudice must be based on the
  entire record and the result will generally turn on the facts of each case.â€ Id.Â  Generally, a curative
  instruction to disregard testimony or evidence is deemed to have cured any
  alleged error. State v. Walker, 366 S.C. 643, 658, 623 S.E.2d 122, 129-30
  (Ct. App. 2005).
In
  this case, Douglasâ€™s prior drug transactions were introduced to explain how
  Officer McLeod knew Douglas was the driver of the vehicle.Â  Douglasâ€™s counsel attempted
  to discredit the eyewitnessesâ€™ testimony by arguing that Douglas drives a white
  Mitsubishi sedan and a black Honda Accord, not a burgundy Buick. Â In response
  to the challenges regarding the Buick driverâ€™s identity, Officer McLeod
  testified he was able to identify Douglas due to prior drug transactions
  involving Douglas. Â Â Â 
Following Officer McLeodâ€™s statement, Douglasâ€™s counsel alerted
  the trial judge that he had a motion to raise. The trial judge denied any
  potential motion by replying, â€œ[w]eâ€™re going forward,â€ and immediately
  instructed the jury they were â€œnot to consider that testimony for any purpose
  than identification.â€ The trial judgeâ€™s comments note that Douglasâ€™s counsel
  opened the door to this testimony by repeated questions of how Officer McLeod
  could identify Douglas in the automobile. The trial judgeâ€™s curative
  instructions further emphasized that Douglas was only charged with distribution
  of crack cocaine resulting from an event on March 15, 2004, and the jury was to
  â€œdisregard any testimony involving any activity of any kind other than if
  [they] care to use it for identification only.â€ 
We find that Officer McLeodâ€™s remarks on Douglasâ€™s prior drug
  sales were allowed into evidence for the purpose of resolving identity, one of
  the five exceptions of Rule 404(b), SCRE, which allows prior bad acts to be
  admitted into evidence.Â  Although the trial court did not conduct a Rule 403,
  SCRE, â€œon-the-recordâ€ analysis in matters pertaining to the admission of prior
  bad acts, the curative instructions evince the trial courtâ€™s clear balancing of
  probative value versus prejudicial effect. State v. King, 349 S.C. 142,
  155-57, 561 S.E.2d 640, 647 (Ct. App. 2002).Â Â  If Douglas was prejudiced, any
  such prejudice was cured by the trial judgeâ€™s curative instruction.Â  The
  instruction was straightforward and refrained from reiterating or emphasizing
  Officer McLeodâ€™s statement.Â  State v. Edwards, 373 S.C. 230, 237,
  644 S.E.2d 66, 69 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  
Furthermore, appellate courts will not generally set aside
  convictions due to insubstantial errors which donâ€™t affect the result. State
    v. Douglas, 369 S.C. 424, 432, 632 S.E.2d 845, 849 (2006).Â  In determining
  if an error is harmless, the appellate court will review the entire record to
  determine what effect the error had on the verdict. Id.Â  â€œAn
  insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where guilt
  has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational
  conclusion can be reached.â€ State v. White, 372 S.C. 364, 386, 642
  S.E.2d 607, 618 (Ct. App. 2007). In the instant case, the State presented testimony from a
  confidential informant who was well acquainted with Douglas, a phone record
  showing Douglas received a call from the location of the drug exchange minutes
  before the transaction occurred, evidence the substance exchanged was crack
  cocaine, and an audio recording of the drug transaction.Â  Â Â 
In addition, Officer McLeodâ€™s testimony could not have affected
  the outcome of the trial because Candrilli previously testified that Douglas sold crack before the event in question. Â Improperly
  admitted evidence is harmless where cumulative. State v. Williams, 321 S.C. 455, 463, 469 S.E.2d 49, 54 (1996).Â  The trial judge interjected a curative instruction ex
    mero motu that the court was permitting the testimony of how Candrilli knew
  Douglas â€œonly as an identification issue and for no other purpose.â€ Douglas did not object. Â Accordingly,
  we can discern no abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s denial of Douglasâ€™s motion for mistrial.
II. Evidence in the Solicitorâ€™s Closing Argument
In his closing argument the solicitor demonstrated that the slip
  of paper Candrilli used on the witness stand in recalling phone numbers was
  torn from his legal pad. The solicitor admitted he wrote some of the phone
  numbers for Candrilli and explained that the slip of paper was only to refresh
  Candrilliâ€™s recollection of phone numbers associated with an incident that
  occurred sixteen months prior to trial. Douglas argues the trial court erred in
  failing to grant a mistrial based on the solicitorâ€™s comments on matters not
  introduced into evidence at trial.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  Douglasâ€™s counsel did not make a timely objection to the solicitorâ€™s closing but instead
  delayed until after the jury had been charged before raising any objections.Â 
  â€œIt is a fundamental principal that a contemporaneous objection is required at
  trial to properly preserve an error for appellate review[2].â€ State v. Black, 319 S.C.
  515, 521, 462 S.E.2d 311, 315 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The proper course of action
  when counsel makes an improper statement is for opposing counsel to immediately object, have a record made of the statement, and ask the court for a distinct
  ruling thereon.Â  Id. at 521, 462 S.E.2d at 315.Â  Failure to object when
  evidence is offered amounts to a waiver of the right to object. Id. at 521-22, 462 S.E.2d at 315.Â  
Even
  if this argument were preserved for appellate review, the solicitorâ€™s
  presentation of the legal pad from which the slip of paper was torn and his
  comments regarding who wrote the telephone numbers on the paper afford no basis
  for a mistrial. 
A solicitor may not rely on statements not in evidence during
  closing argument.Â  State v. Gaines, 271 S.C 65, 66, 244 S.E.2d 539, 540
  (1978).Â  Arguments must be confined to evidence in the record and reasonable
  inferences therefrom, although failure to do so will not automatically result
  in reversal.Â  State v. Copeland, 321 S.C. 318, 468 S.E.2d 620 (1996).Â  A
  new trial will not be granted unless the solicitor's comments so infected the
  trial with unfairness as to make the resulting conviction a denial of due
  process. State v. Coleman, 301 S.C 57, 61, 389 S.E.2d 659, 661 (1990)
  (citing Donnelly v. DeChristoforo, 416 U.S. 637 (1974)).
Here, the solicitor
  improperly introduced new evidence to the jury in his closing argument by
  explaining he wrote some of the phone numbers on the slip and by demonstrating
  the origin of the slip of paper.Â  However, the solicitorâ€™s comments do not
  automatically mandate reversal if they do not result in prejudice to the
  defendant. Gill v. State, 346 S.C. 209, 221, 552 S.E.2d 26, 33 (2001).Â  
â€œNo definite rule
  of law governs finding an error harmless; rather, the
  materiality and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its
  relationship to the entire case.â€Â  State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433,
  454-55, 602 S.E.2d 62, 73 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œIn determining whether an error is
  harmless, the appellate court must review the entire record to determine what
  effect the error had on the verdict.â€ State v. Douglas, 369 S.C. 424,
  432, 632 S.E.2d 845, 849 (2006).Â  Error is harmless where it could not
  reasonably have affected the result of the trial. In re Harvey, 355 S.C.
  53, 63, 584 S.E.2d 893, 897 (2003).Â  Generally, appellate courts will not set
  aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result. Douglas, 369 S.C. at 432, 632 S.E.2d at 849.
Based on the totality of the record we find the solicitor's
  comment, although an improper explanation of the slip of paper Candrilli used
  on the witness stand, was harmless error.Â  First, the solicitorâ€™s
  explanation of the source of the slip of paper did not go to the heart of the
  crime for which Douglas was charged.Â  Whether the solicitor or Candrilli wrote on the slip
  of paper has little if any probative value as to the material elements of distribution
  of crack cocaine.Â  See State v. Black, 319
  S.C. 515, 522, 462 S.E.2d 311, 316 (Ct. App. 1995) (noting whether a trooper
  was or was not driving an unmarked car has little if any probative value as to
  the defendantâ€™s crime of speeding).Â  Second, the solicitorâ€™s explanation
  uncovered conflicting testimony by the Stateâ€™s own witness. The weight of the
  evidence and the credibility of the witnesses are matters within the province
  of the jury. Fortner v. Carnes, 258 S.C. 455, 461, 189 S.E.2d 24, 27
  (1972).Â  Douglas was not prejudiced by the solicitorâ€™s closing argument which
  potentially cast speculation upon the truth of Candrilliâ€™s statements from the
  witness stand.Â  Finally,
  we find the evidence of Douglasâ€™s guilt overwhelming based on (1) testimony by
  Candrilli regarding the drug transaction; (2) the audio recording documenting
  the transaction; and (3) the phone records showing a call was placed from the
  pay phone at Crossroads Grocery to Douglasâ€™s cell phone a short time before the
  transaction occurred.
III. Comments on Drugs in Society During Solicitorâ€™s
  Closing Argument 
At the end of his closing argument, the solicitor acknowledged the
  juryâ€™s decision involved taking Douglasâ€™s liberty but that the juryâ€™s decision
  also affected â€œthe liberty of every youthâ€¦the liberty of every young person,
  every person that goes to Marlboro County High School, every person from this
  entire county.â€ The solicitor also commented on the omnipresent nature of drugs
  when he said, â€œ[i]t is not just stopping here in Marlboro County.Â  It goes to Chesterfield.Â  It goes to Dillon.Â  It goes to Darlington.Â  It goes to North Carolina.Â  It
  goes to everywhere because drugs are a universal problem, and drugs are
  everywhere.â€ Â 
The solicitor concluded by stating, â€œif you today find that the
  evidence is significant enough to find him guilty, I believe that you will be
  doing this community and this society a wonderful, wonderful favor by taking a
  drug dealer off of the streets and placing him where he belongs where he canâ€™t
  do harm to anyone elseâ€¦ [t]hereâ€™s going to be problems butâ€¦the less drug
  dealers there are on the streets, the better off we are.â€ Douglas argues the
  trial court erred in failing to grant his motion for mistrial based on the
  solicitorâ€™s closing argument.Â  We disagree.
Again we note this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  Douglasâ€™s counsel did not make a timely objection to the solicitorâ€™s closing but instead delayed
  until after the jury had been charged before raising any objections[3].Â  Even
  if this argument were preserved for appellate review, the solicitorâ€™s
  discussion of drugs in schools and surrounding counties affords no basis for a
  mistrial. 
The appropriateness of a solicitor's closing argument is a matter
  left to the trial court's discretion. State v. King, 349 S.C. 142, 160,
  561 S.E.2d 640, 649 (Ct. App. 2002). An appellate court will not disturb the
  trial court's ruling regarding closing argument unless there is an abuse of
  that discretion. Id.Â  â€œAn
  appellant must prove an abuse of discretion and resulting prejudice to warrant
  reversal.â€Â  State v. Navy, 370 S.C. 398, 412, 635 S.E.2d 549, 556 (Ct.
  App. 2006).Â  
A
  solicitorâ€™s argument must be carefully tailored so as not to appeal to the
  personal bias of a juror or be calculated to arouse a jurorâ€™s passion or
  prejudice.Â  King, 349 S.C. at 159, 561 S.E.2d
  at 649.Â  When reviewing a solicitorâ€™s closing argument, the court must
  determine if the solicitorâ€™s comments â€œso infected the trial with unfairness as
  to make the resulting conviction a denial of due process.â€Â  Navy, 370
  S.C. at 412, 635 S.E.2d at 556.Â  On appeal, an
  appellate court will review the alleged impropriety of the solicitor's argument
  in the context of the entire record, including the adequacy of the trial
  judgeâ€™s curative instructions and the evidence of the defendantâ€™s guilt. State
    v. Rudd, 355 S.C. 543, 550, 586 S.E.2d 153, 157 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In State
      v. Durden, solicitorsâ€™ closing arguments are discussed as follows:

  â€œSo long as he stays within the record and its reasonable
    inferences, the prosecuting attorney may legitimately appeal to the jury to do
    their full duty in enforcing the law, â€¦and may employ any legitimate means of
    impressing on them their true responsibility in this respect,â€¦[he] may
    illustrate the effect of their verdict on the community or society generally
    with respect to obedience to, and enforcement of, the lawâ€¦ 
  State v. Durden, 264 S.C. 86, 92, 212 S.E.2d 587, 590 (1975) (citing 23A C.J.S.
    Criminal Law Â§ 1107 (2007)).Â  

In
  the instant case the solicitor reviewed the testimony presented to the jury and
  emphasized the important nature of the juryâ€™s decision in regard to the
  community.Â  The solicitor did not implore the jury to
  speak for any victim or beseech them to abandon their impartiality, but instead
  stressed that the jury must weigh the evidence to determine if it is â€œsignificant enough to find [Douglas] guilty.â€ See State
    v. Reese, 370 S.C. 31, 37-38, 633 S.E.2d 898, 901-02 (2006) (holding that a
  solicitorâ€™s Golden Rule closing argument asking jurors to abandon their
  impartiality and view the evidence from victim's viewpoint deprived defendant
  of a fair trial).
We
  hold Douglas was not prejudiced by the solicitorâ€™s general discussion of drugsâ€™
  pervading presence in Marlboro County, its schools, or its surrounding
  counties.Â  After reviewing the entire record we find there was sufficient
  evidence to support the juryâ€™s decision.Â  In this context, the comments on the
  universal nature of drugs during the solicitorâ€™s closing argument were not so
  prejudicial as to deny Douglas a fair trial.
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and
  THOMAS, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] In Toyota of Florence v.
  Lynch, 314 S.C. 257, 442 S.E.2d 611 (1994), South Carolina recognized a
  narrow exception to this rule, but for the Toyota exception to
  apply it must be a case in which a vicious inflammatory argument results in
  clear prejudice.Â  Dial v. Niggel Associates, Inc., 333 S.C. 253, 509
  S.E.2d 269 (1998).Â  That is not the case in this instance.Â  See Toyota of
    Florence v. Lynch (holding that although counsel did not contemporaneously
  object to posters depicting Oriental characters and mushroom cloud explosions,
  in flagrant cases where a vicious inflammatory argument results in clear
  prejudice, a new trial motion should be granted despite the lack of timely
  objection).Â Â  
[3] â€œIt is a fundamental
  principal that a contemporaneous objection is required at trial to properly
  preserve an error for appellate review.â€ State v. Black, 319 S.C. 515,
  521, 462 S.E.2d 311, 315 (Ct. App. 1995).Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Rodell Harris, Respondent,
        v.
        William L. Harris, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Henry T. Woods, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-497 
  Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  16, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; REMANDED


  
    
      
        Jeffrey Raymond Moorehead, of Aiken, for
          Appellant
        Gary Hudson Smith, III, of Aiken, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In
  this divorce action, William L. Harris
  (Husband) claims the family court erred in awarding alimony, equitably dividing
  the marital estate, and awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to his former wife, Rodell
  Harris (Wife).Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
The
  parties were married on March 19, 1982, and separated approximately twenty-one
  years later on October 30, 2003. Â At the time of the final hearing Husband was
  seventy-four and Wife was sixty-six. Â Both parties are retired. No children
  were born into the marriage. 
In
  November 2003, Wife commenced this action by filing a summons and complaint for
  pendente lite and permanent alimony, equitable division of the marital assets
  including the debts, and attorneyâ€™s fees. Husband responded requesting an equitable
  division of marital assets and debts.Â  Husband also requested attorneyâ€™s fees,
  but later withdrew his request during the final hearing. Following a December
  2003 hearing the family court issued a temporary order granting Wife pendente
  lite alimony in the amount of $400 per month. 
At
  the final hearing on July 12, 2006, the family court heard testimony on the
  partiesâ€™ financial standings and a tax debt from 2003. Â Both parties
  also testified regarding their two houses, the nature of their relationship,
  and Husbandâ€™s often uncompromising and sometimes hostile temperament with
  regard to Wife, her family members, his former attorneys, and contractors. 
On
  August 9, 2006, the family court issued a final order (1) granting the parties
  a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation, (2) approving the
  partiesâ€™ stipulated division of personal property, (3) finding Husband had
  greater fault in the breakup of the marriage, (4) directing Husband to pay Wife
  $350 per month in alimony, (5) granting the partiesâ€™ house in Saluda to Wife
  and the partiesâ€™ house in North Augusta to Husband, (6) denying Husbandâ€™s
  request for sweat equity in both houses, (7) finding Wife has no responsibility
  for any of the tax penalties the Husband incurred due to an early withdrawal of
  his savings, and (8) ordering Husband to contribute $5,000 to Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s
  fees. Â Husband appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court has jurisdiction to
  find the facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414
  S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).  However, this broad scope of review does not
  require us to disregard the findings of the family court.  Stevenson v.
    Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).  We are
  mindful that the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses, was in a
  better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to
  their testimony.  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 91, 561 S.E.2d
  610, 613 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Our broad scope of review also does not relieve appellant
  of his burden to convince this court the family court committed error.  Skinner
    v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Alimony
Husband
  claims the family courtâ€™s grant of permanent, periodic alimony and the amount
  awarded constitute an abuse of discretion. Â More specifically, Husband
  argues that Wife can earn enough to support herself, the family courtâ€™s final
  award of alimony was based upon the award of pendente lite alimony at the
  temporary hearing, and the family courtâ€™s finding that he was more responsible
  for the breakup of the marriage erroneously contributed to the decision to
  award alimony. We find no merit in these arguments.
An award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the
  family court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177,
  183-84, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct.
  App. 2001).Â  â€œAlimony is a substitute for the support which is normally
  incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C.
  289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113
  (Ct. App. 1988).Â  The amount
  of alimony is also within the sound discretion of the family court and should
  not be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion is shown. Smith v.
    Smith, 264 S.C. 624, 628, 216 S.E.2d 541, 543 (1975). An abuse of
  discretion occurs either when a court is controlled by an error of law or when
  the order, based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support. Townsend
    v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 70, 73, 587 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  If a
  claim for alimony is well founded, it is the duty of the family court to make
  an alimony award that is fit, equitable, and just.Â  Allen, 347 S.C. at 184,
  554 S.E.2d at 424. 
Â Factors to be considered in making an alimony award
  include: (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health
  of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment
  history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living during the
  marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current
  and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and non-marital
  properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or
  fault; (11) tax consequences; (12) prior support obligations; and (13) other
  factors the court considers relevant. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2006).Â  
A. Wifeâ€™s Income
The
  record reflects that the family court properly considered the statutory factors
  of Section 20-3-130(C) of the South Carolina Code (Supp.
  2006), including the partiesâ€™ age, health, retirement status, duration
  of the marriage, fault in the breakup of the marriage, and substantial
  difference in monthly income before awarding alimony in the amount of $350 per
  month to Wife. Â In its order the family court
  calculated Husbandâ€™s and Wifeâ€™s gross monthly income using the figures
  each party supplied on their 2006 financial statements.Â  The family court noted
  that Wife receives $608 per month from her pension, $1,413.50 per month from
  Social Security, and $72 per month from her investments, resulting in a total
  monthly income of $1,823.50.Â  Husband receives $1,423 per month from his
  pension and $1,160 per month from Social Security resulting in a total monthly
  income of $2,583, which is $760 more than Wife receives each month.Â  
Husbandâ€™s
  argument that Wife can earn enough to support herself fails to illustrate how
  the family courtâ€™s award of alimony was based upon an error of law or a lack of
  evidence.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s award of
  alimony.
B. Previous Award of Alimony
Husbandâ€™s
  second argument that the family courtâ€™s final award of alimony was based upon
  the award of pendente lite alimony at the temporary hearing also fails.Â  The
  temporary hearing in which Wife was awarded pendente lite alimony in the amount
  of $400 per month occurred over two years prior to the final hearing.Â  In
  addition, different judges presided over the temporary hearing and the final
  divorce hearing.[2]Â 
  When a dispute arose during the final hearing regarding both partiesâ€™ failure
  to follow the exact directions of the temporary order, the family court
  remarked that its decisions would not be impacted by another judgeâ€™s long-ago
  ruling on this matter and it could not â€œgo back and undo what was done or was
  not done.â€Â  The family court directly addressed and dispelled the idea at the
  core of Husbandâ€™s argument that the alimony award was fashioned due to a prior
  award of pendente lite alimony.
C. Husbandâ€™s Greater Fault
Husbandâ€™s
  final argument that the family court improperly considered the partiesâ€™ fault
  in the breakup of the marriage also fails.Â  Section 20-3-130(C)(10) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) states that marital fault
  is a proper factor to be considered in the decision to award alimony.Â  
II. Equitable Distribution of Marital Estate
Husband
  claims the family court did not effect an equitable division of the marital
  estate. Â More accurately, Husband argues the family court erred in not
  allocating to Wife part of the nearly $43,000 tax debt incurred by Husband. Â Husband
  also argues the family courtâ€™s finding that Husband is not entitled to sweat
  equity in the partiesâ€™ two houses affected the equitable division of the
  marital estate. Â We agree with Husbandâ€™s assertion that the marital
  estate was not equitably divided, but disagree with Husbandâ€™s contention that
  the family court erred in denying him sweat equity.
A. Tax Debt
Husband
  incurred tax debt in the summer of 2003 when he withdrew money from his IRA but
  did not file a tax return within the appropriate time. Â Husband stated he
  withdrew the money from the IRA because he was not receiving much interest. Â Wife
  first learned of Husbandâ€™s actions when he returned home and told her â€œI cussed
  [the financial advisor] out and took my money out.â€ Neither party knew Husband
  incurred tax liability due to his hasty actions until February 2004. Despite
  being separated, Wife agreed to file a joint tax return which decreased
  Husbandâ€™s tax penalty to $43,000. Â The IRS issued a tax refund in
  response to the partiesâ€™ joint filing, but Wife did not receive any portion of
  the refund. Â 
We
  initially note that neither party nor the family court asserts the tax debt is
  non-marital property. Â Instead, the family court simply apportioned the
  tax debt to Husband in the division of the marital estate.Â  
The apportionment of marital property will not be disturbed on
  appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Bungener v. Bungener, 291 S.C.
  247, 251-52, 353 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp.
  2006) lists fifteen factors for the court to consider in equitably apportioning
  a marital estate. On appeal, this court looks to the overall fairness of the
  apportionment. Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107,
  113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  If the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that the
  appellate court would have arrived at a different apportionment. Id.
Here, the
  family court considered the partiesâ€™ (1) stipulation as to the division of
  marital property, (2) two houses, (3) savings and investment plans, and (4)
  monthly income, as well as (5) the length of the marriage, (6) Husbandâ€™s
  greater fault in the breakup of the marriage, (7) and the alimony award to
  Wife. Â Our review of the record convinces us the family court addressed
  factors under the statute governing apportionment with sufficiency to
  indicate the family court was cognizant of those factors. Â However, we find the
  overall distribution of sixty-three percent of the marital estate to Wife and
  thirty-seven percent of the marital estate to Husband is not equitable for a
  marriage that lasted twenty-one years. See Smith v. Smith, 294
  S.C. 194, 363 S.E.2d 404 (Ct. App. 1987) (preserving a fifty-fifty
  apportionment of the marital estate in an eighteen year marriage); Griffith
    v. Griffith, 332 S.C. 630, 506 S.E.2d 526 (Ct. App. 1998) (approving a
  fifty-fifty division of marital property in a marriage of twelve years).Â  Given
  the trend in case law for an equal apportionment of property in a long-term
  marriage, we modify the family courtâ€™s apportionment of the marital estate by
  awarding Husband forty-five percent of the marital estate and Wife fifty-five
  percent of the marital estate. 
B. Sweat Equity
Husband
  fails to specifically appeal the fact that the family court erred in not
  granting him sweat equity but addresses it in a circumjacent manner claiming
  the absence of such an award affected the equitable division of the marital
  estate. Â We find no merit in this argument.Â  
The
  family court heard extensive testimony regarding Husbandâ€™s work on the partiesâ€™
  houses and even divulged its awareness of the skill and labor required to
  perform the alterations Husband made to the houses.Â  Nevertheless, the family
  court properly found that Husband did not present the proof needed for the
  family court to find the Husbandâ€™s actions merited any special equity in the
  houses. Â See Arnal v. Arnal, 363
  S.C. 268, 294-95, 609 S.E.2d 821,
  835 (Ct. App. 2005) (finding a husband failed to prove his labor made material
  contributions warranting special equity since the husband presented no
  testimony concerning any appreciation in value).Â  The family court also
  noted that both parties contributed different forms of sweat equity throughout
  the twenty-one year marriage and it would be impossible for the family court to
  measure the value of all those contributions. Â Â 
III. Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband
  claims the family court abused its discretion in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to
  Wife. Â Specifically, Husband argues that once he withdrew his request
  for attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should have either abandoned the notion
  of awarding attorneyâ€™s fees or abandoned the partiesâ€™ settlement proposals[3] and awarded attorneyâ€™s fees based on what occurred at the final hearing. Â Husband
  also argues the family court used its award of alimony as a factor in
  determining Husband should contribute to Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees. We disagree.
Whether
  to award attorneyâ€™s fees is a matter within the sound discretion of the family
  court, and the award will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of
  discretion.  Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 633-34, 576 S.E.2d
  156, 167 (2003).  In determining whether an award of attorneyâ€™s fees
  should be granted, the family court should consider the following: each
  partyâ€™s ability to pay their own fee, the beneficial results obtained by
  counsel, the financial conditions of the parties, and the effect of the fee on
  each partyâ€™s standard of living.  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471,
  476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).  To determine the amount of attorneyâ€™s
  fees to award, the family court should consider the nature, extent, and
  difficulty of the services rendered; the time necessarily devoted to the case;
  counselâ€™s professional standing; the contingency of compensation; the
  beneficial results obtained; and the customary legal fees for similar
  services.  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d
  313, 315 (1991).
We
  find no abuse of discretion in the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The family court adequately
  considered the factors set forth in Glasscock when awarding attorneyâ€™s
  fees to Wife.Â  There is no indication alimony was a factor in the attorneyâ€™s
  fees.Â  Further, Wife obtained a beneficial result that was appropriately
  considered by the family court.Â  
CONCLUSION
We affirm the
  ruling of the family court in regard to the award of alimony, the refusal to
  award sweat equity, and the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We reverse and remand to
  the family court for re-allocation of the marital estate in accordance with
  this opinion.
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED
  IN PART AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON and THOMAS, JJ.,
  and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The Honorable Peter R. Nuessle conducted the
  temporary hearing and issued the temporary order. The Honorable Henry T. Woods
  conducted the final divorce proceeding and issued the final order which Husband
  now appeals. Husband does not appeal the temporary order.
[3] The record on appeal did not contain the partiesâ€™
  pre-hearing settlement proposals.Â  From the Husbandâ€™s argument and the family
  courtâ€™s reference to its review of the settlement proposals, this court can
  infer that the settlement proposals of both parties may have discussed awarding
  attorneyâ€™s fees.

title: Gore v. Beneficial Mortgage
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				John A. Gore, Respondent,
				v.
				Beneficial
      Mortgage Co. Of South Carolina, Appellant
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball, III, Special Circuit
  Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-498
Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  25, 2007
APPEAL DISMISSED WITHOUT PREJUDICE


	
		
			
				C. Mitchell Brown, B. Rush Smith, III, Thad H. Westbrook, and Christina
  Rampey Hunoval, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
				John Martin Foster, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER
  CURIAM:Â  Beneficial Mortgage Co. of South Carolina (Beneficial) appeals the special circuit judgeâ€™s order granting John Goreâ€™s
  (Gore) motion to restore his case to the active docket.Â  We dismiss the appeal
  without prejudice.[1]
FACTS
On December 1, 2003, Gore filed a
  complaint against Beneficial, alleging Beneficial failed to enter satisfaction
  of a mortgage given to it by Gore.Â  Beneficial responded to the complaint in
  its answer filed on February 6, 2004.
The
  master-in-equity assigned to hear the case as a special circuit court judge
  sent a form letter to Goreâ€™s counsel, dated August 5, 2004, requesting counsel
  send a reference fee to the judge in order to go forward with the case.[2]Â  The letter stated â€œ[i]f the fee is
  not received within 30 days from the date of this letter, the case will be
  dismissed for failure to prosecute.Â  The case will not be restored to the
  roster of cases except upon motion to restore and a showing of good cause.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The trial judge, in an order filed September 24,
  2004, dismissed the action sua sponte for failure to prosecute.[3]Â  Gore did not appeal the order or
  move for reconsideration under Rule 59, SCRCP.
On
  November 11, 2004, Gore filed a motion to restore pursuant to Rules 40 and 41, SCRCP.Â  The special circuit court judge, by order filed on May 11, 2005,
  restored the case to the non-jury trial docket.Â  The judge, in his order,
  explained the â€œaction was dismissed with the right to restore for good cause.â€Â 
  The judge found â€œthe parties were engaged in settlement negotiations at or
  about the time the order of dismissal issued.â€Â  In granting the motion to
  restore, the court â€œnoted its use of such orders as a sanction, and its
  practice of allowing reinstatement based on a liberal construction of â€˜good
  cause.â€™ â€Â  The judge, observing â€œthe body of law dealing with default in which
  the adverse party is required to show prejudice,â€ specifically found that
  restoration of the action would not prejudice Beneficial.Â  Beneficial now
  appeals the special circuit judgeâ€™s order granting Goreâ€™s motion to restore.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Beneficial argues
  the special circuit judgeâ€™s order of dismissal for failure to prosecute
  dismissed the action with prejudice and operated as an adjudication on the
  merits.Â  Alternatively, Beneficial argues that even if the order did not
  dismiss the action with prejudice, the special circuit court judge no longer
  retained jurisdiction to act upon Goreâ€™s motion to restore.
Our supreme court
  has held â€œ[t]he decision on a motion to restore the case to the active docket
  is not a final judgment and is interlocutory and, therefore, not immediately appealable.â€Â  Shields v. Martin Marietta Corp., 303 S.C. 469, 470, 402
  S.E.2d 482, 483 (1991).Â  It is well settled that an interlocutory order is not
  immediately appealable unless it involves the merits of the case or affects a
  substantial right.Â  Brown v. County of Berkeley, 366 S.C. 354, 361, 622
  S.E.2d 533, 537 (2005); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (1977 & Supp. 2006).Â 
  Because Beneficial is appealing the grant of Goreâ€™s motion to restore, the
  appeal is interlocutory and therefore not properly before us.Â  See Shields,
  303 S.C. at 470, 402 S.E.2d at 483 (1991) (noting the â€œ[a]voidance of trial is
  not a â€˜substantial rightâ€™ entitling a party to immediate appeal of an
  interlocutory order.â€) (quoting Blackwelder v. State Dept. of Human Res., 299 S.E.2d 777 (1983).
Subject
  matter jurisdiction is the power to hear and determine cases of the general
  class to which the proceedings in question belong.Â  Majors v. South Carolina Secs. Comâ€™n, 373 S.C. 153, 159, 644 S.E.2d 710, 713 (2007).Â  We believe
  the special circuit court judge in this case had the power to hear and
  rule upon Goreâ€™s motion to restore.Â  We note the â€œ â€˜difference between a want
  of jurisdiction in which case the court has no power to adjudicate at all, and
  a mistake in the exercise of undoubted jurisdiction in which case the action of
  the trial court is not void although it may be subject to direct attack on
  appeal.â€™ â€Â  Fryer v. South Carolina Law Enforcement Div., 369 S.C. 395,
  399, 631 S.E.2d 918, 920 (Ct. App. 2006) (quoting Thomas Howard Co. v. T.W.
    Graham Co., 318 S.C. 286, 291, 457 S.E.2d 340, 343 (1995).Â  â€œ â€˜When a court
  acts with proper subject matter jurisdiction, but takes action outside of its
  authority, the party against whom the act is done must object and directly
  appeal.â€™ â€Â  Id., (quoting Coon v. Coon, 356 S.C. 342, 347-48, 588
  S.E.2d 624, 627 (Ct. App. 2003), affâ€™d as modified, 364 S.C. 563, 614
  S.E.2d 616 (2005)).
Having found
  Beneficialâ€™s appeal to be interlocutory, we are precluded from addressing the
  remainder of the appeal.Â  See Brunson v. American Koyo Bearings,
  367 S.C. 161, 165 n.1, 623 S.E.2d 870, 872 n.1 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding the
  dismissal of an appeal as interlocutory precludes the court from addressing the
  remaining issues).
APPEAL DISMISSED
  WITHOUT PREJUDICE.
ANDERSON and THOMAS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  South Carolina Code section 14-11-310 (1977 &
  Supp. 2006) permits a master-in-equity to charge fees in cases referred to him
  or her in their capacity as master.Â  Here, however, the master sat as a special
  circuit court judge.
[3]Â  The order dismissing the action did not mention the
  possibility of returning the case to the roster upon a motion to restore and a
  showing of good cause.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        John Copeland, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
  Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-499
  Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  29, 2007

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Eleanor Duffy Cleary, South Carolina Commission on Indigent
          Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        J. Benjamin Aplin, Â of the South Carolina Department of Probation,
          Parole & Pardon, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER
  CURIAM:Â  John Copeland appeals the circuit courtâ€™s revocation of his
  probation from his conviction for threatening the life of a public official.Â  Copeland
  argues the circuit court erred in revoking his probation without providing appellant with an opportunity to be
  heard.Â  We find this argument not preserved for
  our review because Copeland failed to voice any objections at the revocation
  hearing.Â  See State
    v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361,
  380, 580 S.E.2d 785, 795 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œArguments not raised to or ruled
  upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  Copelandâ€™s
  counsel has petitioned to be relieved as counsel, stating that he has reviewed
  the record and has concluded Copelandâ€™s appeal is without merit.Â  Copeland has
  not filed a pro se Â brief.Â   
After a thorough
  review of the record pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738
  (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we
  hold there are no directly appealable issues that are arguable on their
  merits.Â  Accordingly, we dismiss this appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be
  relieved.[1]
APPEAL

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      Ex Parte:
      
        Shawnee Holdings, LLC, Appellant,
        In Re: MidFirst Bank, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Ricky Ray Truitt a/k/a Ricky Truitt and Jackie Lee Truitt f/k/a Jackie Runyon, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-501
  Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  29, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Randall L. Hartman, of North Myrtle Beach, for Appellant.
        John J. Hearn, Reginald P. Corley, and Robert J. Thomas, all of
          Columbia and William Young, of North Myrtle Beach, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Shawnee Holdings, LLC (Shawnee), a third-party purchaser,
  appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s order setting aside a foreclosure sale and asks
  this Court to set aside a subsequent foreclosure sale.Â  We affirm in part and
  remand.
FACTS
Ricky Ray Truitt
  and Jackie Lee Truitt (Truitts) obtained a mortgage on property in Little
  River, South Carolina, from Mortgage Electronic Registration Systems (Mortgage
  Electronic).Â  Eventually, the Truitts stopped making payments on the mortgage.Â 
  Mortgage Electronic foreclosed on the subject property, and a foreclosure sale
  was held in Horry County on June 5, 2006.[1] Â Mortgage Electronic gave bidding instructions to its attorney regarding the
  maximum bid Mortgage Electronic would make on the property.Â  Mortgage
  Electronic authorized a bid not to exceed $120,505.32.Â  Mortgage Electronicâ€™s
  attorney forwarded the bidding instructions to Mary Alice Hendrick (Hendrick),
  who has been responsible for handling the bidding in judicial sales at the Horry County courthouse for twenty to twenty-five years.Â  However, when the bidding began,
  Hendrick stopped bidding at $85,000.Â  As a result, Shawnee purchased the
  subject property for $85,000.Â   
Mortgage Electronic made a motion to set aside the
  foreclosure sale on the basis of bidder mistake.Â  At the hearing on the motion,
  Hendrick testified to the circumstances surrounding the sale and to the fact
  that she has handled the bidding for the Horry County courthouse for twenty to
  twenty-five years.[2]Â 
  Hendrick testified she had â€œno clueâ€ as to what happened the day of the sale and
  described her failure to continue bidding as a â€œtotal mistake.â€Â  Â Â 
The master entered an order setting aside the June 5,
  2006 foreclosure sale pursuant to Rule 60(a), SCRCP, on the basis of bidder
  mistake.Â  The property was then resold at a subsequent foreclosure sale on
  August 7, 2006.Â  Shawnee made a motion to have the subsequent sale set aside.[3]Â 
  The master did not rule on this motion.Â  This appeal followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA mortgage foreclosure is an action in equity.Â  Our
  scope of review of a case heard by a master who enters a final judgment is to
  determine facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.â€Â  E. Sav. Bank, FSB v. Sanders, 373 S.C. 349, 354, 644 S.E.2d
  802, 805 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  â€œHowever, the determination of whether a judicial
  sale should be set aside is a matter left to the sound discretion of the trial
  court.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe review of a judicial sale is equitable in nature and
  within the discretion of the trial court.â€Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Setting Aside the
  Second Sale
Shawnee argues the
  second foreclosure sale should be set aside because the thirty-day appeal
  period stemming from the first foreclosure sale had not expired prior to the
  second sale.Â   
This Court follows
  the well-settled rule that unless a question has been presented to the court
  below for consideration, we will not consider the question on appeal.Â  Williamson
    v. S.C. Elec. & Gas Co., 236 S.C. 101, 107, 113 S.E.2d 345, 348
  (1960).Â  â€œAn appellate court exists for the correction of errors committed in a
  lower court, and if such court has not had the opportunity to decide the
  question presented, there is no error for the appellate court to correct.â€Â  Id.Â  There must be some evidence in the record that the question was presented to or
  passed upon by the court below for this Court to address that question.Â  Cooper
    v. Firemenâ€™s Fund Ins. Co., 252 S.C. 629, 634-35, 167 S.E.2d 745, 748
  (1969).Â   
Shawnee filed a
  motion to set aside the second foreclosure sale but never gave the master an
  opportunity to rule upon the motion before filing and serving the present
  appeal to set aside both foreclosure sales.[4]Â 
  Shawnee filed the motion to set aside the second sale on the same day the
  notice of appeal was filed.Â  In order to appeal the second sale, the motion
  must have been raised to and ruled upon by the master.Â  Shawnee failed to seek
  a ruling from the master regarding the second foreclosure sale; accordingly,
  the issue of setting aside that sale is not ripe for our review.Â  We remand the
  issue to the master to determine whether Shawnee is entitled to have the second
foreclosure sale set aside.Â Â Â  Â 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Order Setting
  Aside First Sale
Shawnee contends the
  master erred in setting aside the first foreclosure sale based on bidder
  mistake.Â  We disagree.  
South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure empower the court to correct clerical errors
  and mistakes in judgments and orders.Â  Rule 60(a), SCRCP.Â  Rule 60(a) provides
  in pertinent part: â€œClerical mistakes in judgments, orders or other parts of
  the record and errors therein arising from oversight or omission may be
  corrected by the court at any time of its own initiative or on the motion of
  any party and after such notice, if any, as the court orders.â€Â  By definition,
  a clerical error is a mistake in writing or copying, and â€œ[a]s applied to
  judgments and decrees, it is a mistake or omission by a clerk, counsel, judge
  or printer which is not the result of exercise of judicial function.â€Â  Dion
    v. Ravenel, Eiserhardt Assoc., 316 S.C. 226, 230, 449 S.E.2d 251, 253 (Ct.
  App. 1994).Â  Rule 60(a) has been found to be an appropriate mechanism for
  setting aside a judicial sale where a court employee commits a clerical error.Â  See Goethe v. Cleland, 323 S.C. 50, 53, 448 S.E.2d 574, 575 (Ct.
  App. 1994) (finding the clerk of courtâ€™s typographical error concerning the
  time period in which bidding would remain open was a clerical error).Â  Â 
Under the facts of
  this case, we find the error made in the bidding process to be clerical in
  nature. Â Rule 60(a), therefore, provided the master with discretion to correct
  the mistake and set aside the foreclosure sale.Â  Shawnee argues Hendrick was
  actually an agent for Mortgage Electric, and the master did not have discretion
  to correct the agentâ€™s mistake.Â  Â Â 
When deciding
  issues on appeal, this Court is confined to the record.Â  Timms v. Timms,
  286 S.C. 291, 294, 333 S.E.2d 74, 75 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  To find an agency
  relationship, the record must provide at least some evidence to support that
  finding.Â  See Young v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Disabilities & Special Needs,
  374 S.C. 360, ___, 649 S.E.2d 488, 492 (2007) (finding the record was devoid of
  any evidence to support a conclusion of an apparent agency relationship).Â  Â Â Â 
In the present case, the record is devoid of any
  evidence establishing an agency relationship between Hendrick and Mortgage
  Electronic.Â  The only evidence in the record indicates Hendrick has handled the
  bidding in the Horry County courthouse for twenty to twenty-five years.Â 
  Although Shawnee argues Hendrick was actually an agent for Mortgage Electronic
  at the time she was handling the bidding in the foreclosure sale, Shawnee failed to present any evidence to support this argument.Â  Without evidence of
  Hendrickâ€™s relationship to Mortgage Electronic, we cannot find that there was
  an agency relationship between the two. Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the order of the master is
AFFIRMED IN PART AND
  REMANDED.[5]
STILWELL, SHORT, and
  WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.



[1] The name of the Respondent is MidFirst Bank on the
  briefs and record, but apparently, Mortgage Electronic and MidFirst Bank are
  related or share the same interest.
[2] At the time of bidding, Hendrick was the secretary
  for Circuit Court Judge John Breeden.Â   
[3]Â  Shawnee alleges it did not receive written notice of
  the order setting aside the first sale until August 16, 2006, nor did it have
  notice of the subsequent sale.Â  The motion to set aside the sale and the notice
  of appeal were both filed and served on September 12, 2006.Â   
[4] Both parties stated in their briefs the master
  informally notified them he would not rule on the motion to set aside the
  second sale due to the filing of the notice of appeal.Â   
[5] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Caniskey Horton, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-502
  Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed October
  29, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant
          Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Kevin Scott
          Brackett, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Caniskey
  Horton appeals his convictions for murder, assault and battery with intent to
  kill (ABIK), and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent
  crime.[1]Â 
  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
In the early morning hours of December 21,
  2002, Caniskey Horton fired his gun five times in the parking lot of The Money
  night club.Â  He shot and injured Matthew Cousar (Cousar) and shot and killed
  Jacques Cousar (the deceased).Â   
Horton
  and four others (Hortonâ€™s group) drove to The Money in Rock Hill, South Carolina.Â  Hortonâ€™s group enjoyed their time at the club without incident and then
  exited into the parking lot at approximately 3:30 a.m.Â  Cousar and five others
  (Cousarâ€™s group) exited The Money at approximately the same time.Â  The groups noticed
  that a car had parked very close to a car belonging to a member of Cousarâ€™s group.Â 
  A member of Cousarâ€™s group commented on the parked car as Hortonâ€™s group passed.
Cousar
  allegedly yelled as Hortonâ€™s group began to drive away.Â  The driver of the
  Horton groupâ€™s vehicle stopped, rolled down the window, and asked Cousar: â€œWhat
  did you say to me?â€ Â Cousar replied that he was talking about the parked car.Â  Cousar
  testified that the Horton group driver then swore at him.Â  Cousar then stated that
  none of the people in Hortonâ€™s vehicle were soldiers.[3]Â  Horton exited the vehicle and
  approached Cousar.Â  There are conflicting accounts of the events following this
  point.Â   
Cousar testified he could see that Horton cocked a gun and placed
  it in his jacket upon exiting the vehicle.Â  Horton testified he did not have
  the gun at that time. Â Cousar admitted he then struck Horton in the head with a
  violent blow that knocked him to the ground.Â  The force of the blow either
  dislodged the gun from Horton, or Horton reached into the vehicle for the gun.Â 
  Two members of Hortonâ€™s group exited the vehicle and helped Horton back to his
  feet.Â  One of these two men may have handed Horton his gun.Â   
It is clear that Horton ultimately fired the gun five times in the
  direction of Cousarâ€™s group.Â  Three of the bullets hit the deceased and one hit
  Cousar.Â  Immediately following the shooting, Horton and his group exited the
  parking lot in their vehicle.Â   
The
  trial court sentenced Horton to concurrent sentences of thirty-five years for
  murder, twenty years for ABIK, five years for possession of the firearm, and
  one year for unlawfully carrying a pistol. Â This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn
  criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ Â State
    v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  An appellate court
  will not reverse the trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding jury charges absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).Â  â€œAn abuse
  of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law
  or, when grounded in factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.Â  Â Â Â Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Horton contends
  the trial court erred in its
  instruction to the jury because it was inconsistent with the facts of the case.[4]Â  We disagree.
During
  the pre-charge conference, Horton objected to the Stateâ€™s requested charge that
  words alone were not sufficient provocation to justify voluntary manslaughter.Â 
  Horton argued that because Cousar initially struck him, an instruction on â€œwords
  aloneâ€ was improper. The trial court charged in part:  
The provocation needed for voluntary manslaughter must come from
  some act of or related to the victim or victims.Â  Words alone however vulgar or
  insulting are not enough to be legal provocation.Â  Where death is caused by the
  use of a deadly weapon the words must be accompanied by some overt threatening
  act which could have produced the heat of passion.Â  The exercise of a legal
  right no matter how offensive it is to another is never sufficient legal
  provocation for voluntary manslaughter.
Horton argues this charge does not apply to the facts of this case
  and merely confused the jury.Â  Jury
  instructions must be considered in their entirety and, if in their entirety,
  they are free from error, then any potentially misleading portions do not
  constitute reversible error.Â  State v. Jackson, 297 S.C. 523, 526, 377
  S.E.2d 570, 572 (1989).Â  In its entirety, the jury instruction accurately informed
  the jury that words alone are insufficient legal provocation to justify
  voluntary manslaughter.Â  The instructions also informed the jury that an overt threatening act could have produced
  the heat of passion necessary to justify voluntary manslaughter.Â  The jury was
  aware that Cousar struck Horton prior to the shooting and was free to find this
  to be the required overt act.Â  We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s charge to
  the jury.Â  Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, Hortonâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.



[1] Â Horton does not appeal his conviction for
  unlawfully carrying a pistol.  
[2] Â We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] Â Slang indicating the Horton group was not
  â€œtough.â€Â   
[4] Â The State argues this issue is not preserved
  for our review because Hortonâ€™s objection was not sufficiently specific.Â 
  Horton objected to the jury instruction stating it went further than the facts
  of the case and that it was uncontradicted that Cousar hit Horton.Â  We find
  Hortonâ€™s objection sufficient to preserve the issue for appellate review.

PER CURIAM:Â  David

  to instruct the jury regarding self-defense.[2]Â 
  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(c), SCACR, and the following authority: Jackson
